title: eu asks united states to reconsider covid 19 travel ban
story: US president Donald Trump speaks with Rodney Scott, the US Border Patrol Chief, as he tours a section of the border wall on Tuesday in Arizona. Photograph: APThe European Union has stepped up efforts to persuade the United States to exempt EU citizens legally residing in the US from the travel ban, as both sides consider the next stage in opening-up borders for international travel in the wake of coronavirus.In a letter to US secretary of state Mike Pompeo last week, EU ambassador Stavros Lambrinidis and Croatia’s ambassador to the US, whose country holds the rotating EU presidency, asked the US to reconsider the scope of the current travel ban imposed by the US in March to take account of Europeans living in the US on non-immigrant visas.Thousands of Europeans are employed under various categories of so-called “non-immigrant” visas in the US, but under the terms of the travel ban which applies to most European countries, China and Iran, they are unable to re-enter the United States if they visit those countries.The European Commission already offers more flexibility to non-EU nationals, and has recommended that third-country nationals, including Americans, legally residing in the EU should be exempt from travel restrictions.Ban on visasOn Monday, US president Donald Trump announced a ban on issuing new non-immigrant visas to foreign workers for the rest of the year, though those who are already living and working in the United States on visas are not affected. However, the presidential order means that thousands of people who had expected to travel to the United States for work later in 2020 will be unable to do so.Discussions between inidual embassies and the EU mission in Washington are taking place with the administration and the State Department on possible exemptions to the travel restrictions or a standardised approach by the two blocs. Other categories of foreign residents in the United States are permitted to re-enter, though they must abide by quarantine and other health requirements in each state on their return. In the letter, the ambassadors point out that current US coronavirus travel rules mean that EU citizens resident in the United States are banned from entering the US if travelling from the Schengen area or Ireland.The diplomatic push comes amid reports that the EU could ban US travellers from entering the Schengen area as it considers taking a coordinated approach among member states to reopening the bloc’s external borders from July 1st.The US has reported more than 2.3 million cases – the highest in the world – with top immunologist Anthony Fauci warning on Tuesday of a “disturbing surge” in infection rates in some US states.One possibility is that both blocs could maintain restrictions on tourist visitors, but have different arrangements for those ordinarily resident in either the EU or the US.Less than five months before the presidential election, immigration is returning to the political agenda in the United States.Border wallMr Trump toured a section of the border wall in Arizona yesterday, as he made a trip to the electorally-important state.Stating that illegal immigration was down 84 per cent compared to a year ago – a figure that has been impacted by the coronavirus pandemic – Mr Trump said that no administration had done more to secure America’s southern border.“Our border has never been more secure,” he said, accusing presidential rival Joe Biden and Democrats of wanting “open borders” and “criminal sanctuaries”.Mr Trump inspected a section of a 320km segment of the steel wall, signing a plaque attached to the barrier. Earlier, he described the structure as “just about unclimbable”, and “the most powerful” barrier in the world.Mr Trump’s visit to Arizona came a day after he signed a presidential order expanding immigration restrictions, by halting the issuance of new visas for certain categories of foreign workers until the end of the year. He also extended a ban on green card applications until at least next year. Speaking at the border wall on Tuesday, Mr Trump defended the move, stating: “we want to give jobs to Americans right now”. But he hinted that some breakthrough on DACA – the programme that protects young Americans who arrived in the country illegally as children – could be imminent.Everything you need to know about the Covid-19 outbreakStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: us democratic
story: The process to choose the Democratic nominee to take on Donald Trump in November’s US presidential election is well under way.States across the country are in the process of choosing&nbsptheir preferred candidate, either through a primary contest or a caucus. A primary is a traditional election where eligible voters select their candidate privately through a ballot system. A caucus is a public process which sees voters align publicly with their chosen candidate at caucus sites.Based roughly on their share of the vote in each state - states have different rules -&nbspcandidates are assigned a number of “delegates”, which will be sent to represent each state at the Democratic National Convention in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, in July.On March 3rd – Super Tuesday – 14 states and one overseas territory voted. After a faltering start to the primaries that almost saw him written off, former vice-president Joe Biden got his campaign firmly on track with victory in nine states. Though Vermont senator Bernie Sanders finished first in four states, including delegate-rich California, Super Tuesday checked the Sanders momentum after a strong opening to the primaries in Iowa, New Hampshire and&nbspNevada.On March 10th&nbspsix more states vote, with most of the remaining primaries taking place throughout March and April. The final primary contest takes place on June 7th. However, by the end of March, well over 50 per cent of the delegates will have been allocated.In order to be selected as the party’s nominee at the convention in July, a candidate needs a majority of 50 per cent of delegates plus one, so the magic number is 1,991 pledged delegates out of the total of 3,979.However, with four candidates remaining in the race - Elizabeth Warren and Tulsi Gabbard complete the field, after Michael&nbspBloomberg’s&nbspwithdrawal -&nbspit is possible that no one candidate will have a majority of delegates when Democrats convene in July.Though the rules were changed after the 2016 convention following tensions between the Sanders and Hillary Clinton campaigns, so-called superdelegates - unpledged delegates - still play a role. These are senior members of the party – governors, former members of Congress, etc. Their 771 votes come into play if the convention is contested, which is&nbspa possibility.Notably, six of the candidates were asked during a debate in Las Vegas on February 19th if they would support the idea of a candidate winning the nomination if they secured a plurality but not a majority of the delegates. All but one – Sanders – said they were opposed to this. The issue may become a headache for the Democratic Party as the primary process progresses.

title: give back old normal lockdown took away freedoms
story: When a rattled-looking Boris Johnson popped onto our television screens on March 23 to announce the most significant restrictions on British life and liberty in peacetime, he promised a review within three weeks.Few would have guessed that three months later many of the measures would still be in place. At the time, there had been 350 deaths from Covid-19 in the UK. Today there have been close to 40,000. That grim figure explains why the Government has retained the controls over social interactions, albeit with modifications as the pace of contagion has slowed.Now that it has almost halted, Mr Johnson is emboldened to relax the restrictions further and, in delivering better news, he certainly looked far more chipper in the Commons than he has done for a while, back to the old Boris.But listening to his statement about what we are now permitted to do was to appreciate in the starkest terms what it is that we have lost. For a country that is defined by its love of freedom to be told that we can go to the pub, though only if we supply our names and addresses to the innkeeper or can get our hair cut, though only if our coiffeur dresses like a nuclear power plant worker or we can have a dinner party but must not embrace or kiss our guests, these are hard orders to take, even if they are dressed up as “guidance”. As a law-abiding nation, we take these things seriously even when they are not actually the law of the land as many of these “rules” are not, including the two-metre distancing.Many restrictions seem arbitrary. Why, for instance, is professional football allowed but not cricket? This makes no sense since the former involves much more close contact. Mr Johnson said the ball in cricket acted as a vector for disease but on that basis the game will never restart.We were promised Independence Day on July 4 but remain in chains, even if they are looser than before. Even when we are freed, which will not happen this year because of the Government’s fear of a second wave, much will have changed.Looking through my wallet yesterday was like a Proustian journey into a past life. Photo-passes to offices  I no longer visit an oyster card for trains that I no longer use a library card for books no longer borrowed and even some cash – remember that? These may well be the detritus of a world never to be regained. Will those of us able to work at home ever be allowed back into the office or even want to go for that matter?I had thought that once this nightmare was over, we would all be commuting into cities again, eager to return to the camaraderie and woke minefield of modern office life, but I have my doubts now.Parents whose children have been at home since March and face another two months with the little darlings cannot wait to get back to the office but once the schools have returned they might think differently. Home working by millions will be an abiding legacy of this time with all the implications that will have for the viability of public transport, commercial property management and businesses like cafes, restaurants and taxis that rely on commuters for their livelihoods, especially in London.Foreign travel will change even when the 14-day quarantine for all arrivals is dropped. While there are many people desperate to get back to the beaches of the Med, there are others who find the thought of a masked four-hour queue at the airport intolerable. Eating out, going to the cinema, attending the theatre – all these activities are to reopen but their pleasures constrained by pettifogging rules and for how long?What else will change? The BBC has been running a series of podcasts called Rethink in which leading figures in their fields consider what might happen. One contributor, Lady Hale, the former president of the Supreme Court, suggests that we might reconsider how we use juries in criminal trials.This has been a theme recently among jurists alarmed at the growing backlog in the system. One proposed “temporary measure” is for judges to sit alone or with a couple of lay assessors rather than with a full jury in order to get through the mountain of pending trials. But it would not be a temporary measure. Once introduced it would be hard to get rid of it. Do we want the “new normal” to erode our ancient juridical rights?Or what about Parliament: when will it go back to proper functioning? Now that voting is carried out remotely or by proxy, do we ever see the old system returning or a full complement of MPs allowed back to Westminster? What will that mean for the scrutiny of legislation which was never especially well done and has been almost non-existent in recent weeks?Research by the Hansard Society think tank found that more than  90 pieces of legislation, including significant restrictions on people’s freedoms, were pushed through without parliamentary scrutiny. We have lost a great deal in the past few months. We cannot dispense with our democracy as well.Do events like a pandemic create a new reality or accentuate changes that were already lurking beneath the surface? Notwithstanding the death toll, this has not been the catastrophic plague that some had feared and has mercifully spared the young almost entirely, unlike past contagions. Moreover, when Mr Johnson announced what he acknowledged to be an unprecedented curtailment of inidual freedom, he said the aim was to prevent the NHS being overwhelmed.That justification passed some time ago and yet the Government still thinks it should dictate how we conduct our lives, including our most intimate contacts. Provided the people most likely to succumb to the virus are protected then everyone else should be allowed to carry on and assess the risk (low for most) to themselves.Our freedoms cannot continue to be restricted by a fixation on R numbers or assumptions that there will be a “second wave” of the virus which, as Liam Fox said in the Commons, is merely the continuation of a disease that we cannot get rid of and have to live with. The “new normal” is a world devoid of light and liberty. I want the old normal back, please.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: activists target holland park statue lord linked slavery abolition
story: One of London's wealthiest neighbourhoods could be renamed as part of review into links to slavery after the statue of an aristocrat who helped abolish the trade was vandalised.The wealthy west London area of Holland Park was named for colonising courtier Henry Rich, 1st Earl of Holland, whose family profited from slavery and ultimately gave its name to a Kensington park and Tube station.These could be reviewed after a local monument to his descendant Henry Vassall-Fox, 3rd Baron Holland, was daubed with red paint and topped with a sign referencing his ownership of slaves.The Whig statesman technically owned slaves through his wife’s estate, but consistently opposed the trade and was part of the 1807 and 1833 governments which pushed through abolition.The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea where the statue stands indicated the monument could be placed under review as part of a “conversation about the figures we see in our public realm” adding London “must oppose racism in all its forms”.As part of the capital-wide reevalution of links to slavery and colonialism, the area boasting the most expensive residential street in England could be reviewed for links to the Holland lineage, along with the local park, Tube station, and electoral ward of the same name.The area’s history has been questioned after activists targeted the bronze likeness of Lord Holland, topping it with a sign stating “I owned 401 slaves” and daubing this number on the plinth in red paint along with handprints.This number appears to refer to slave holdings in Jamaica he came to possess through his socialite wife’s family, and compensation received after abolition.Lord Holland, who died in 1840, was a Whig luminary who opposed to the trade and was part of the brief government in 1807 which passed the first Slave Trade Act. He was also praised by key abolitionist William Wilberforce for being a “most zealous partisan” for abolition.Red graffiti was removed from his statue by borough staff, but the monument’s future could now be in doubt under Sadiq Khan’s new review of public sites and spaces with nefarious links.  This could apply to the park where the statue stands, and the broader area named after Holland House, titled by first Lord Holland, an eventually executed Cavalier sympathiser.He oversaw the colonial Providence Island Company which ultimately made use of slaves.A spokesman for Kensington and Chelsea  said: “The Mayor of London has launched his London-wide public realm review and we expect this to consider station names, statues and street names.“Any decisions will need to take into account the views of local people and we are absolutely committed to representing the views of residents in our erse communities in Kensington and Chelsea.”The Mayor of London’s office has said while its new commission is being established to review the public realm, further details on the future of debate districts are not available.The targeting of Lord Holland’s statue comes after campaigners previously targeted similarly ambiguous figures like William Ewart Gladstone, who initially supported compensation for slave holders such as his father, but personally opposed the trade.Lord Holland’s monument was not on the frequently updated “hit list” of monuments posted on the “Topple the Racists” website established in the wake of Black Lives Matter protests.Experts at University College London have said the claims he owned 401 slaves may not be clear-cut, and there may have been a family trust controlled for his slave-owning wife, and their children.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality title: betrayed eu italy turning china
story: Back in 2008, in the middle of the great financial crisis, Lake Superior State University declared that the most overused expression in the English language that year was “perfect storm”. Twelve years later, this meteorological metaphor – of a critical and dangerous situation created by a rare and powerful concurrence of events or circumstances – seems fitting when contemplating the current threat posed by China to a deeply troubled Europe.  China will likely stop at nothing to fulfil predictions that the 21st century will be the “Chinese century”, a century geopolitically dominated by China, and a marked transition from the 20th “American century”. And if, as official data currently suggests, China is able to keep future outbreaks of Covid-19 under control, then it will no doubt look to capitalise wherever possible for its own economic, commercial, and political advantage.  The existential threat facing the EU, meanwhile, cannot be underestimated. Although we have seen the EU bounce from crisis to crisis over the past 10 years, it seems that, in the face of the Covid-19 pandemic – ironically a crisis originating almost certainly in China – the decisions the EU takes now will be a defining moment for the future of European integration. This combination of a China looking to exert and strengthen its global power and a Europe battling for its very survival has sadly created a truly perfect storm. And it is Italy – which was one of the EU’s most struggling countries financially pre-Covid-19, and which has been arguably the hardest hit by the virus – that sits firmly in the eye of this storm.As Italy faces its most severe crisis since the Second World War, with more than 35,000 Covid-19 deaths and its economy on course to suffer the deepest recession in modern history, there is a rising feeling within the country that it is being abandoned by its neighbours. China, meanwhile, is clearly looking for a major “satellite” in Europe, or, more politely, for a more permanent entry-point to the continent. And Italy would appear to be an obvious choice. As one of the G7 advanced economies and the second-largest manufacturer in the EU, it would be quite a catch. Put bluntly, Italy’s feelings of betrayal by its European partners, Germany in particular, seem to coincide  unfortunately with Chinese attempts to deepen its penetration of Europe. And an Italy reeling from the fallout from coronavirus, and from previous woes, may, by providing China with a willing partner on the continent, be the weak link in the EU’s approach to Beijing and to the defence more generally of European values.We have witnessed this crisis magnify the economic and political isions between northern and southern Europe that have long threatened to tear apart the EU.When Italy appealed to the rest of the EU for assistance, it was initially rebuffed. Italy, and the rest of southern Europe, had hoped for a real demonstration of solidarity from the rest of the EU early in the pandemic. And even if the EU has subsequently increased assistance in the form of financial aid and equipment, the initial hopes and expectations were by no means met. Last month, the new European Commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, tacitly admitted this, offering Italy a “heartfelt apology” for not having done more to help.But was this act of contrition too late? With regards to Italy in particular, it is a situation that has been brewing for quite some time. Italy’s economy has barely grown since the launch of the euro in 1999. “Reforms” were imposed on the country during the financial crisis and it has seen its status as one of the “big three” founder-members of the EU, alongside France and Germany, effectively downgraded.A migrant crisis in which, again, Italy was hit hard and the EU faced accusations of a lack of solidarity, merely added to the resentment. It is, therefore, unsurprising that, long before coronavirus was a word on most people’s lips, Italy last year signed up to China’s Belt and Road initiative, a hugely ambitious scheme to drive trade links via infrastructure projects from the Far East into the heart of Europe. It was the first major Western country to do so.Perhaps fittingly, an early symbol of Italian participation in this scheme was to be found in Chinese involvement in the deep-water port city of Trieste in the Adriatic, once part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire and ceded to Italy after it joined the Allies during the First World War. Trieste has long been considered the European terminus of the maritime Silk Road from the Far East to Europe, a key trade route for about 2,000 years until the 1700s, which is thought to be a key inspiration for the Belt and Road project.Of course, European partnership with China is not confined to Italy. George Osborne, Chancellor from 2010 to 2016, ignored US opposition and signed the UK up for Beijing’s Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, widely seen as a rival to the Washington-based World Bank. Neither is Italy alone in feeling bruised by its treatment by its EU partners after bearing the initial brunt of the coronavirus crisis. Spain harbours similar feelings of neglect.Nevertheless, it is Italy that will surely be the immediate battleground for any clash of ideas and ideals between China and the EU. And unless bold action is taken by northern European countries, there is a very real risk of Italy turning its back on the European project forever and potentially turning to China. The EU must take significant measures to support and protect both Italy and wider EU integration. As Donald Tusk, now president of the European People’s Party, notes: “We must save Italy, Spain and the whole of Europe and not be afraid of extraordinary measures. This is a state of emergency.” Italy itself must also look to do everything it can to be as attractive as possible to foreign investors and businesses. There must not be overwhelming bureaucracy or an ineffective legal system preventing investment into the Italian economy. Reform in these areas – in Italy and across southern Europe generally – is long overdue and cannot be delayed any longer. We must hope that EU leaders and their Western allies take action now. They will not get a second chance – especially as an opportunistic China lurks in these unchartered waters. Nicole Junkermann is the founder of NJF Holdings, an international investment companyMore from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: coronavirus qa expert answers travel questions
story: The recent easing of lockdown restrictions and reports that air bridges could be introduced in the coming weeks have given Britons fresh hope that foreign holidays could still go ahead before the summer months come to a close. But there are still signs that when holidays return, the options for where Britons can travel to and what they can do on those trips will be limited.As the uncertainty continues, the 's Chief Consumer and Culture Editor, Nick Trend, answered your most pressing questions on refunds, travel restrictions and the proposed air bridges scheme. I'm due to fly on holiday on July 29. The problem is I'm shielding and the government has said that's in place until August 1. If I go on holiday on July 29 will my insurance be void?It depends on your policy and the condition which means that you have to shield. I’m not sure if you want to travel, or if you would like to cancel, but either way your best bet is to talk to your insurer and – most importantly your GP. If your doctor says it is safe to travel, that should be enough to convince your insurer. If they say it isn’t safe, then you may be able to activate the cancellation clause in your policy.We are due to fly from Portugal to Faro on July 5. Sunshine holidays say we can’t transfer our holiday and if we cancel we lose our money. The hotel is open and they said that we have to wear masks and gloves while around the pool area and in restaurants. Has an air bridge been agreed with Portugal? Why is it Ryanair can carry on selling flights for July when only essential travel is allowed?We expect some news to be announced about reciprocal arrangements which will allow travel to Portugal in the next couple of days. If that is the case, then your holiday will most likely go ahead and you won’t be able to transfer or cancel. If the FCO continues to recommend against travel, you should be able to get a refund. I’m afraid the issue of masks and gloves is an unpleasant side effect of the global emergency and there probably isn’t much which can be done about it.I am due to travel on July 8 for a stag party. But I am unable to quarantine when I return due to work commitments, am I able to get a refund? I am flying with Ryanair.It depends on your destination. There are several factors at play – are you allowed to socialise in groups the size of your party, for example? It may well be that air bridge arrangements to be announced in the next couple of days will remove the need for quarantine, but only a few countries will be covered. Either way, if your flight is operating, you are unlikely to be able to get a refund.We booked a safari holiday in Kenya for August 11 for a party of 4 people. We have paid the full amount. If they ask us to defer our holiday for next year and cancel again, will we still be covered by our travel insurance? Or is it best to see if we can get our money back?You’d need to check with your insurer. But you would probably need to renew the policy - in which case, check that it still has the levels of cover that you need - many policies have been altered since the outbreak of the pandemic. Personally, I’d be inclined to ask for a refund, but if there is no extra charge for deferral, it might be better to do that, since holidays are likely to be more expensive next year.We have a villa booked with TUI in October in Cyprus. We can defer it until next year (we still have to pay the remaining money in July) but two people have medical problems and at the moment Cyprus is not accepting British visitors. As I don't want to lose my deposit I would consider paying extra to defer the holiday. What should I do?TUI is allowing bookings before August 31 to be deferred, but it is unlikely to be extended as far as October. I also think Cyprus is likely to be open to UK visitors by then. So you need to weigh up your options. If you friends are unable to travel for medical reasons, the cancellation charge may be covered by your insurance. If not, much depends on how much you have paid for your deposit, and whether you are happy to lose it. No easy answer I’m afraid.Last week we received a call from our holiday company asking if we are looking forward to our holiday to Mauritius this July. We were somewhat shocked as we presumed that this would be cancelled but we were told that it is likely to go ahead. Do you think this is actually possible as we really don’t want to travel at the moment?You don’t say when in July that you are due to travel. If the FCO revises its warning against overseas travel and includes Mauritius in the list of destinations it considers safe before you are due to depart, then it is likely that your holiday will go ahead. If you really don’t want to go, talk to the operator and see if it will allow you to postpone it - otherwise I’m afraid that if you don’t go, you may have to forfeit the cancellation charges, which are likely to be high so near to the departure date.I live in Scotland where the current guidance is to only travel 5 miles from home. I have a holiday booked in England from July 3. If the situation remains the same but the agent says I can have the week I have booked, where do I stand? It seems likely holidays in Scotland will start on July 15, but on July 4 in England. Should I go? If I don't will I have to pay the balance and also lose my deposit?That’s an incredibly awkward situation! But, as I write this I hear that Nicola Sturgeon is planning to relax the rules so that you would be able to travel to England by the date in question. But I assume also you have booked a holiday cottage and  I would point out that  it is not legal to stay overnight on holiday in England on the night of July 3. So I think the agent ought to offer you the option to cancel, since it can’t fulfill the original contract.Your best bet is to  speak to the agent and try to sort it out. You might also point out that there is huge demand for cottages and that, if you do cancel it shouldn’t be difficult for the agent to re-let it and so give you a refund.Hoseasons Boating holidays on the Norfolk Broads are scheduled to restart on July 3 and we are booked on a boat for the end of July, but as a shielded inidual I am unlikely to be able to take my holiday then. Do I have the right to a refund if I cancel?If you are shielding and you have a doctor’s letter to say that it is not safe for you to travel on that date then your travel insurance may well cover the cancellation costs. If you don’t have insurance, then talk to Hoseasons. They are a reputable company and I think it is unlikely that they will force you to cancel in those circumstances. A full refund is unlikely however, they may well offer a deferral instead. How likely is it that British overseas territories such as Bermuda will be included in the air bridge scheme?There is a good chance Bermuda will be included - an official announcement is likely in the next couple of days.We booked our holiday through Loveholidays in February to go to Salou for 20 nights on July 7. However we were notified last week that the flights have been cancelled and we cannot get in touch with loveholidays. They have taken the rest of the money for the holiday today.If your holiday has been cancelled, you are entitled to a refund. I’m sure Loveholidays will be in touch. If not, please do contact asktheexperts@telegraph and we will help if we can.When will coach day trips be allowed again? I have booked a day trip for 24 people (all aged over 65). The trip is due to take place on July 2. I have not heard anything from the coach company yet.Many of the 24 people are very wary of going on the trip due to ongoing health problems. I do not want to cancel it because we would all lose our money.Is it best to wait for the coach company to contact me with the hope that they will hopefully cancel the trip? Yes – don’t cancel unilaterally or you will lose your money. I’m sure the company will cancel and if it does, you should be given a refund.Our Jet2 flights to Alicante on July 4 have been cancelled. We have rented a villa via a well established Spanish villa rental company and currently are having problems with them in regard to them explaining their coronavirus cancellation policy. All we want to know is what are our options. Thus far we have not received any answers to our question. This is extremely worrying as the cost of the villa was over £4000.I’m afraid this is one of the risks of making independent travel arrangements rather than booking with an operator. Assuming the company is based in Spain, you are subject to the law there and I’m afraid you may struggle to get a result. However, it may well be possible to find alternative flights with another airline – either to Alicante or Valencia, and it is looking possible that a deal may be in place to allow you to travel from the UK to Spain by July 4 – so it is possible that you will be able to salvage your holiday after all.Leave your questions for our next Q&ampA in the comments section of this article or email them to yourstory@telegraph. If you would like to remain anonymous please disclose this when you ask your question.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: dont look now britains v shaped economic recovery has already
story: The economic recovery is already taking shape nicely – and the shape looks increasingly like a V after all. Despite this, many commentators are still pessimistic and even eager to emphasise the downside risks. It is time to view the glass as half full instead.Let us start with what we already know. The economy shrank by an unprecedented 25 per cent in just two months between February and April, but it could have been even worse. The Office for Budget Responsibility’s projections for the public finances are still based on a 35 per cent fall in GDP, sustained for a full three months. The Bank of England had warned of a 30 per cent decline.What’s more, there is now ample evidence that April was indeed the trough, and that activity picked up sharply in both May and June, even while large parts of the economy were still in lockdown. This evidence includes surveys of business activity, such as the Purchasing Managers Indices (PMIs) published by Markit. The handful of official numbers released so far have generally been better than expected too, including a 12 per cent jump in retail sales last month.Indeed, both the OBR and the Chief Economist of the Bank of England, Andy Haldane, have now acknowledged that the economy is performing less badly than either had predicted. Even the record level of Government borrowing is slightly below the path that the OBR had pencilled in.Of course, it is still too much to hope for a neatly symmetrical V-shaped recovery, where GDP returns to its pre-crisis level as quickly as it fell. But the latest data suggest that the UK economy should get back close to this level much sooner than many had anticipated, and the picture will look far more like a V than the U, or even L, that some had feared.Indeed, I’d go further and say that an initial V is now nailed on. Some people will understandably be reluctant to venture out and spend, even if they are allowed to do so. But the latest polling suggest that a clear majority of the public support the further easing of the lockdown.In the meantime, some households have been hit disproportionately hard, including many poorer families and the self-employed. Many of those on the Government’s furlough scheme are worried about losing their jobs when it ends. Nonetheless, most households have actually built up their savings during the lockdown. Pent-up demand is therefore still likely to be strong.So, why the continuing pessimism? In part this may reflect several biases, some of which are more forgivable than others: bad news usually sells better than good news, many commentators are reluctant to appear complacent in the midst of a pandemic and may simply want to see more evidence, while others would never want to appear to give any credit to a Government led by Boris Johnson.But to be fair to the pessimists, there is also still a chance that the initial V-shaped recovery is just the first stage of a W. This double dip scenario could come about for one or both of two reasons.First, there could be a devastating second wave of the coronavirus itself. This would presumably force the Government to reimpose the lockdown, or at least prompt many consumers and businesses to behave as if it had. Others are better qualified than me to judge the likelihood of this happening, although most of what I have seen suggests that this risk is now small and that the UK is much better prepared than it was in March.Second, the rise in unemployment so far might only be the tip of a very large iceberg. It is certainly possible that many more job losses will follow in the coming months as the furlough scheme is wound down. But again, I think it right to be relatively optimistic.Crucially, the further easing of the lockdown is running well ahead of the timetable for scaling back the employment subsidies. There is also still more that the Government could do, should this be needed. However, the UK’s relatively flexible economy and labour market is pretty good at creating jobs on its own, if allowed to do so.In short, ever since the early days of the coronavirus crisis, pundits have been debating how quickly activity would rebound when the lockdown is lifted, or indeed whether it could recover at all. Thus far, the evidence points to a pleasant surprise.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: hungry monkeys run riot thai temple town
story: Residents of the ancient Thai city of Lopburi are living in fear of marauding gangs of monkeys, as thousands of primates brawl with each other, attack shops, and take over the streets in search of food during the coronavirus lockdown. Lopburi province and the antics of its macaques have long lured hordes of foreign tourists who pose with them for selfies in exchange for free bananas.  But as tourism dried up because of the global pandemic so too did the monkeys’ food supplies, prompting a violent turn in their behaviour.  Local efforts to offer the monkey mobs some nutrition may have backfired as some say a sugary diet of fizzy drinks, cereal and sweets has fuelled the animals’ sex lives, making their population grow even more. The more they eat, the more energy they have... so they breed more, Pramot Ketampai, who manages the city’s Prang Sam Yod temple shrines, told AFP.Monkeys patrol the walls of the temple, in the centre of the 800-year-old city, to protect their turf.  In March, they staged a brazen raid on another group of monkeys living around the Phra Kan Shrine, on the prowl for temple offerings. Their invasion – captured in a video that went viral on social media - resulted in a vicious street fight that stopped traffic for ten minutes as the rival gangs screeched, charged at each other and engaged in paw-to-paw combat.  “They’re so used to having tourists feed them and the city provides no space for them to fend for themselves,” Supakarn Kaewchot, a government veterinarian told Reuters. “With the tourists gone, they’ve been more aggressive, fighting humans for food to survive,” she said. “They’re invading buildings and forcing locals to flee their homes.”The human population has had to continue with uneasy coexistence as parts of city cede complete control to the monkeys. An abandoned cinema has reportedly become the primates' headquarters, with the projection room turned into a cemetery where the monkeys lay their dead to rest. A nearby shop owner said he displayed stuffed tiger and crocodile toys to try to scare off the creatures and prevent them from snatching spray-paint cans. We live in a cage but the monkeys live outside, said one resident, Kuljira Taechawattanawanna. Their excrement is everywhere, the smell is unbearable especially when it rains.For years, city residents have had a love-hate relationship with their monkey neighbours, who attract tourist dollars but regularly create mayhem, breaking windows, stealing groceries and damaging cars. But the worsening fights, along with reports of locals barricading themselves in their homes, and no-go zones for humans, have prompted the authorities to intervene, restarting a sterilisation programme after a three year pause. Wildlife department officers have placed big cages around the city, filling them with fruit to lure the animals inside and then take them to a clinic where they are anaesthetised, sterilised and left with a tattoo to mark their neutering. They aim to treat hundreds out of the 6,000-strong macaque population within the next few weeks. More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe title: marilyn monroes lost handkerchief saves paris theatre financial
story: It is a happy ending not to be sneezed at.A handkerchief belonging to Marylin Monroe has single-handedly saved a historic Paris theatre from bankruptcy after its owner auctioned the legendary Hollywood actress’s ephemeral possession for €300,000 (£270,000). For decades, the silk kerchief with floral embroidery and bordered by ivory lace had pride of place in the baroque hall of the Comédie Italienne,  France’s only theatre dedicated to Italian commedia dell’arte, in Paris’ Left-Bank 14th arrondissement.Its owner, Attilio Maggiulli, kept it as a lucky charm and the item even inspired a play two years ago called “Le Mouchoir de Marilyn” (Marilyn’s Handkerchief) in which the star has a love child with John F Kennedy, who interns the actress in a care home.According to Mr Maggiulli, the handkerchief came into his possession after a series of cross-Atlantic twists of fate.A concierge at New York’s luxury Waldorf Astoria hotel first found the item in the toilet of the room in which Monroe had been staying in 1960, he told Le Parisien.He offered it to pop art icon Andy Warhol who in turn passed it on to the illustrious art gallery owner Leo Castelli.In 1983, Mr Castelli gave the unused hanky to Mr Maggiulli as a keepsake at a time when he was renting him out a small theatre space in Soho in New York.Almost 40 years later, the nonconformist Italian said the gift had proved a godsend for the theatre, which was facing financial ruin in February shortly before the coronavirus pandemic struck, despite donations from patrons.Reluctantly, he contacted a group of wealthy fans of the theatre and organised a private auction.The handkerchief went to an unnamed bidder described as “someone who adores the theatre and admires Marilyn,” according to Mr Maggiulli’s associate, Claudine Durand-Simone.“We were able to reimburse colossal debts and the mortgage is paid,” Ms Durand-Simone told Le Parisien. “It was a happy surprise.”Despite the financial boost, the theatre is still for sale after 46 years in the hands of its Italian boss.However, here too, the tale may have a happy ending. According to the owner, just before Paris went into lockdown in March, a couple of affluent theatre-lovers visited the venue and talks over a sale are at an “advanced stage”. The potential new owners have reportedly offered to buy the theatre but allow the Comédie Italienne to continue its shows eight months of the year. All of France's theatres were closed during nationwide confinement that started on March 17. While all have been allowed to reopen this month, many are remaining shut until September due to draconian health restrictions and problems rescheduling plays.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: rules lockdown new uk update
story: The move will enable pubs, restaurants, cinemas and other businesses to be run profitably when they are allowed to reopen on the same day, and will change the way in which schools, shops, transport and workplaces can operate.Mr Johnson told MPs the rate of infection in the community – as opposed to hospitals and care homes – is now low enough to relax the social distancing rule as long as steps are taken to mitigate the risk of people being closer together.Face coverings will be needed in some indoor locations, perspex screens could be used between tables in restaurants and al fresco dining will be encouraged to minimise the risk of transmission.A Downing Street spokesman said: After a long period of asking the public to follow very strict and complex rules, the Government believes we are now in a position to enable people to see more of their friends and family.The infection rate has fallen significantly in the first half of June. Only one in 1,700 people have the virus, compared with an average of one in 400 a month ago.Where it is not possible to stay two metres apart, people are advised instead to keep one metre plus apart – meaning one metre apart plus mitigation.But I must say to the House it will be all too easy for that frost to return. And that is why we will continue to trust in the common sense and the community spirit of the British people to follow this guidance, to carry us through, and to see us to victory over this virus.From July 4, any two households can meet together under the same roof, and even stay overnight, as long as they observe social distancing. That means families could invite one set of grandparents over for lunch and then see the other set of grandparents for dinner, as long as they are not there at the same time.The new rule also allows any two households to meet up in a pub, restaurant, museum or cinema, or even go on holiday together. There will be no limit on how many people can gather, as long as no more than two households are meeting at the same time.The Government decided against an alternative plan to allow two entire households to form one social bubble, partly because it would have forced families to choose which set of relations they could see.Existing rules allowing up to six people from up to six different households to meet outdoors remain in place, as does the rule that allows someone living alone to join a support bubble (see below) with another household and be treated as if they live in the same home.Downing Street admitted people would need to show a lot of discipline and restraint to adhere to the new rules, such as preventing children from hugging grandparents, but stressed that the changes would be swiftly reversed if coronavirus started to spread again.A Number 10 spokesman said: Your household will be able to link with one other household at a time, which includes staying over at someone's house.This is not a bubble because households should continue to remain socially distant from one another when they are indoors or outdoors, so they will need to stay two metres apart or follow the new one-metre plus advice.This will allow customers to sit closer together in venues in which it is not possible for them to be two metres apart, so long as there are additional mitigating measures in place. New safety guidance, due to be issued later, will set out a menu of options for hospitality bosses to use as part of the new system. These include more back-to-back seating, perspex screens, partitions between tables, disposable menus and more cleaning of commonly touched surface areas. Waiters will be required to wipe down surfaces more often and collect glasses and plates more frequently. People will be discouraged from returning their glass or ordering from the bar, with more table service and mobile apps expected to be introduced. The changes will also place limits on the number of people who can sit together indoors in pubs and restaurants, with just two households of any size permitted to drink or eat together. To assist the Test and Trace system, customers will be required to register their details with a venue before entry.Hairdressing salons will be able to reopen, but the experience of getting your hair cut is likely to be very different.Hairdressers will be required to wear a full-face plastic visor to reduce the risk of infection and will also need to follow strict rules over the disinfecting of equipment.Customers will have to make appointments, and there will be limits on the amount of people in salons. It is also anticipated that hairstylists will be told to cut down on small talk.But the mass reopening will come with a number of conditions attached. Recommendations to stop coronavirus from spreading include emptying mini bars, offering buffet-free breakfasts and regularly deep cleaning rooms, with 24 hours left between bookings.All paperwork is likely to be removed from rooms, along with the telephone, while the plastic pouch containing tea and coffee sachets will either be removed or quarantined for up to 72 hours between guests.Those checking in should expect to see social distancing stickers on the floor, perspex screens at the reception desk and hand sanitiser available throughout. It is thought campsites will be instructed to ensure that tents are pitched further apart than normal so social distancing measures can be adhered to, along with frequent deep cleaning of facility blocks such as showers. Some campsites will be required to reduce the number of pitches to keep numbers down. Campers are likely be told they cannot have day visitors in order to further limit the numbers on site. Communal areas such as receptions, shops, laundries and playgrounds are likely to remain closed, with guests advised to bring all their own essentials, including gas canisters.As with hotels and other overnight accommodation, guests will be asked to pay in advance and use contactless payment rather than cash. Changes to the rules, allowing two households to meet up, mean that two families will now be able to go on holiday together.The Prime Minister confirmed: From July 4, provided that no more than two households stay together, people will be free to stay overnight in self-contained accommodation, including hotels and bed and breakfasts.Mr Johnson did not specifically mention Britain's 2.2 million shielded people in his statement.However on Monday, Matt Hancock, the Health Secretary, announced that this extremely clinically vulnerable group would finally be able to meet friends and visit relatives' homes from July 6.Shielded people, considered to be the most medically vulnerable to the effects of coronavirus, including those with lung conditions and people being treated for cancer, will be able to meet up to five other people outdoors after having been virtual prisoners in their own homes for the past three months.If they live alone they will also be able to form a support bubble with one other household, meaning they can visit their families and stay overnight with them. It is hoped the infection rate will be low enough for shielding to end all together at the end of July, though help will still be available from NHS volunteers and local councils.As long as they continue strict social distancing measures, shielded people will be able to visit supermarkets and places of worship, and those who cannot work from home will be able to return as long as their workplace adheres to Government guidance.Until now, the only easing of lockdown for shielded people has been allowing them to go outside once a day with their household or, if they live alone, to meet one other person at a two-metre distance.It advises that shielded children can return to school in line with their peers, provided they wash their hands frequently and adhere to social distancing. Mr Johnson said that Easter, Passover and Eid all occurred during the lockdown and he was pleased to announce that places of worship will reopen for prayer and services, including weddings with a maximum of 30 people, all subject to social distancing.Weddings will restart from July 4, with up to 30 people able to attend under social distancing rules. Lockdown is easing - but here's are the things you still can't doSwimming pools and water parksBowling alleys and indoor skating rinks Nail bars and beauty salons  Indoor fitness and dance studios, and indoor gyms and sports venuesfacilities Exhibition or conference centres From July 4, provided they are Covid-19 compliant:Restaurants, cafes, bars and pubs             Cinemas and bingo halls       Theatres and concert hallsMuseums and galleries            Outdoor playgrounds, gyms, and skating rinks         Funfairs, theme parks and adventure parks and amusement arcades       Aquariums, zoos, safari parks, farms, wildlife centres and any place where animals are exhibited as an attractionMore from title: travel news eu could ban american tourists summer
story: British holidaymakers could travel to Spain this summer if the two countries secure an &#39air bridge&#39What are the candidates for an 'air bridge'?When will destinations reopen to British tourists? Listen to our brand new travel podcastForeign holidays will be a step closer when UK air bridges are announced, which could be as soon as Monday.The  understands the first of these bilateral travel agreements – which would  circumvent quarantine – will be with Portugal, Greece, Spain, Bermuda, Gibraltar and the Canary Islands. Demand for overseas trips could spike once details are confirmed. As it stands, the Foreign Office (FCO) advises against all but essential travel, so travelling abroad would invalidate travel insurance. Meanwhile, the UK Government’s quarantine measures require all arrivals to the country, including returning Britons, to self-isolate for 14 days. But FCO advice is expected to change once air bridges are announced, and quarantine should be waived for those visiting countries with which the UK has secured a travel corridor.By Monday, Britons should have a clearer idea on where they can travel this summer. However, this does not necessarily mean that prices for holidays and flights will go up. Industry leaders and experts told  Travel while demand will increase for holidays when travel restrictions are lifted, prices could broadly remain the same. The UK travel market is incredibly competitive and offers extremely good value for money, prices are generally governed by supply and demand,” said a spokesperson for ABTA, the UK travel trade association for tour operators and travel agents.“Hotels, airlines and tour operators will set their prices to encourage sales and will be preparing now to tap into a rush of bookings expected once travel restrictions are lifted, they added.Read Greg Dickinson’s report on whether flight and holiday prices are set to increase in the next week, and when is best to book.And follow the latest travel news below. Here are the key developments from today:Bookings surge for UK holidays following confirmation of July 4 restart (in England)The EU may ban American tourists this summerMales will welcome back foreign tourists from July 15The Azores have been declared Covid-freeSelf-catering holidays allowed in Scotland from July 3As each region of the UK prepares for tourism to return, a cruise around home shores may be the answer for those missing life afloat, reports Benjamin Parker.For cruise lovers who are miserable at being landlocked, unable to reach the shores of the Caribbean or Australia this year – or, in the case of the Seychelles, until 2022 – a cure may be found close to home.In fact, there’s a flutter of confidence that the hoops Britons must currently jump through to travel abroad could result in a surge of travellers looking to take to the waves around Britain.Scotland and its islands, in particular, have been earmarked by cruise insiders as somewhere to watch, with one operator telling The  that despite such trips being domestic travel they “will be very attractive for those wishing for a real escape”.Read the full story.Hazel Plush asked tourism boards across England if, after months of asking visitors to stay away, they are ready for the lifting of restrictions on July 4.Malcolm Bell, chief executive of Visit Cornwall, said: “It wasn’t that we didn’t want you to stay away forever – it’s because we cared about you, and the people of Cornwall! We were the first English tourist board to ask people to stay away, and that message was absolutely vital at the time, but now – at last – it is changing.”Read the full story.Staycations can begin from next month in England, but when are the UK's best hotels set to reopen? We've updated our list of key dates for properties in England, Scotland and Northern Ireland, along with guidance on what to expect during a post-lockdown hotel stay.Hotel Endsleigh, in Devon&#39s Tamar Valley, reopens in JulyThe Azores have been declared free of the coronavirus. The Portuguese archipelago, which is due to reopen to international visitors on July 1, was recently included on a list of safe destinations compiled by the pan-European tourism board, European Best Destinations. The government plans to pay for travellers' Covid-19 tests when they arrive if they can't prove they have tested negative in the previous 72 hours.Luís Capdeville Botelho, director of the Azores Tourism Board, said:The Azores Islands are delighted to have been recognised by the European Best Destination Organisation as the safest place to travel in light of the pandemic and can today proudly declare the islands COVID-19 free, with no active cases reported. This pandemic has put life into perspective for us all, no matter where we live, which language we speak and what we believe in. It has taught us that nothing can be taken for granted and that it took us to pause as a human race in order to come through the dark times. From now on we are sure that people will cherish the safety of the Azores Islands, a destination which has always prided itself on its commitment to welcoming visitors with open arms, with their wellbeing at the forefront of our minds.We are immensely proud of the swift action taken by the Portuguese government, tourism industry and local establishments here on the islands to ensure that we can return to a state of normality, with the utmost safety measures in place to maintain this.Acrobats performed gravity-defying stunts above Les Diablerets in Switzerland yesterday. The Glacier 3000 air show marked the reopening of the tourism facilities. Travel restrictions in Scotland that require residents to stay within five miles of their home will be lifted from July 3 and self-contained holiday accommodation will be allowed to reopen, first minister Nicola Sturgeon has announced. Scottish pubs can reopen from July 6 and the rest of the hospitality industry can follow suit from July 15.The first minister warned if Covid-19 starts to take hold again then the easing of lockdown restrictions “will be halted”.Telegraph Travel's chief consumer editor, Nick Trend, offers his insight in the video below. We also hear from Portugal and Croatia's tourism boards.There has been a huge surge in bookings for UK holidays since Boris Johnson confirmed the hospitality industry can reopen in England from July 4, reports Annabel Fenwick Elliott.Self-catering accommodation and campsites have seen interest soar, while Cornwall and Devon are among the destinations proving most popular. Two of the UK’s major brands – Hoseasons and cottages – enjoyed their best ever online sales days yesterday. The former recorded one booking every 11 seconds in the hours after the announcement, and the latter saw a 455 per cent surge.Read the full story. The Indian Ocean archipelago will welcome back international visitors from July 15, President Ibrahim Mohamed Solih announced yesterday. Resorts and hotels on uninhabited islands can open to guests on July 15, while guest houses and hotels on inhabited islands can reopen from August 1. Foreign visitors will not be required to take a Covid-19 test to enter the country, but authorities will carry out temperature checks and other screening measures.Those displaying symptoms will be tested at their own cost. If they test positive, visitors will be required to self-isolate. Iata, the International Air Travel Association, which represents the world's airlines, has warned that so long as countries have quarantine measures in place, people will not travel. It has suggested alternatives to isolation plans, including testing, contact tracing and minimising the risk of contracting coronavirus while travelling. Safely restarting the economy is a priority. That includes travel and tourism. Quarantine measures may play a role in keeping people safe, but they will also keep many unemployed.The alternative is to reduce risks through a series of measures. Airlines are already offering flexibility so there is no incentive for sick or at-risk people to travel. Health declarations, screening and testing by governments will add extra layers of protection. And if someone travels while infected, we can reduce the risk of transmission with protocols to prevent the spread during travel or when at destination. And effective contact tracing can isolate those most at risk without major disruptions.Imposing quarantine measures on arriving travelers keeps countries in isolation and the travel and tourism sector in lockdown.The UK is due to review its lockdown on Monday, June 29, with air bridge agreements likely to be announced. Following yesterday's announcement, many will be planning their next staycation. Emma Cooke has everything you need to know about booking an Airbnb property in the UK (or Europe). Read the full story.Ready to book your next staycation?Camping and glamping booking website Cool Camping saw a surge in traffic following yesterday's announcement that accommodation providers can reopen from July 4.We saw an instant fourfold increase in bookings compared to before the announcement and our bookings are up some 750 per cent on this time last year. This illustrates a huge amount of pent up demand to get away in the UK this summer,” said Jonathan Knight, founder of Cool Camping.Campsites in England can reopen from July 4 while Scottish campsites are hopeful that the provisional date to reopen on the 15th July will be confirmed soon. We've rounded up Britain's most gloriously spacious campsites.Paul Sullivan reveals how giving up alcohol made him a more appreciative traveller – and set him on a journey of self-discovery. The most awkward moment of my new life of sobriety occurred in Russia in 2019 – back in the good old days when we could gather fearlessly in small venues – at a swanky cocktail bar in Moscow.A traditional drinks menu was trendily superseded by an explanation of the bar’s concept from a bearded barman. At the end of a five-minute monologue extolling the benefits of handmade syrups, seasonal mixers and boutique spirits, I had to explain demurely that I was teetotal.A momentary look of confusion on his face dissolved into disbelief and, a second later, stunned laughter – loud, dry, incredulous laughter that ricocheted around the bar like a thunderclap, turning the heads of nearby patrons. He hadn’t meant it in any offensive way, he explained. It was just that the concept of being alcohol-free was strange to him, and more so in a cocktail bar the irony of the bar being called voda (“water”) did not escape us. The dainty, alcohol-free strawberry martini he made for me completed my emasculation in the eyes of the liquor-swilling punters all around me.Despite such episodes, the past year or so of living and travelling without booze has been wholly positive.Read the full story.Temperatures should continue to climb this week – London is set to be hotter than Ibizia – and many Britons are soaking up the coastal sun.Lifeguards keep watch in Weymouth, Dorset, todayThe busy beach at WeymouthA dog enjoys a dip in the sea at South Gare near Redcar, North YorkshireEuropean Union countries could block visitors from the US due to America's failure to effectively tackle the coronavirus outbreak. Brussels has drawn up two draft lists of acceptable travellers ahead of its July 1 border reopening, according to The New York Times. America is not named on either list. The US has recorded more than 2.4 million cases of the virus and over 123,00 deaths, the highest rates in the world. Southern states, including Georgia, Florida, South Carolina and Texas, have a recent uptick in cases.EU borders have been closed to most of the world since mid-March while a number of countries began to lift travel restrictions for the Schengen area, and some for the UK, from June 15. Brazil and Russia, which have recorded the second and third highest number of cases worldwide, are also excluded from the EU draft lists. China, where Covid-19 is thought to have originated, is included on both lists. The US banned travel from most European countries in mid-March. After initially leaving the UK off its restricted list, the ban was soon extended to Britons. In an exclusive interview with the  earlier this month, Dr Anthony Fauci warned that British holidaymakers could be banned from travelling to the US for months, dashing hopes of summer trips to America. Around 3.8 million Britons visit the US each yearEngland might be in the throngs of a heatwave but Down Under snow has been falling and Australia’s ski resorts have reopened, reports Lucy Aspden.Lifts in Thredbo in New South Wales and Mount Buller in Victoria began turning on Monday, followed by the country’s most popular resort Perisher plus Mount Hotham and Falls Creek in Victoria today.Australian resorts follow the lead of their southern hemisphere cousins in New Zealand, which reopened earlier this month.Life on the slopes looks a lot different to what keen skiers and snowboarders are used to. Capacity on the mountain is reduced, group lessons are banned and all lift passes need to be purchased online in advance – a move that has left many without a spot back on the slopes.While lift tickets for Thredbo sold out in record-breaking time, Vail Resorts, the ski giant that operates Australia’s Perisher, Falls Creek and Mount Hotham, has given holders of its Epic Australia Pass the option to apply for refunds, understanding the impact of the pandemic on the ski season may deter a lot from visiting.Ski resorts in 10 countries across the world have now reopened, including some in the Alps that have access to high-altitude snow-sure glaciers such as Cervinia in Italy and Tignes in France.Devon’s Burgh Island Hotel, known for inspiring an Agatha Christie novel and unusual location on a private tidal island, has announced it will reopen on July 7, reports Emma Beaumont.The hotel, which can only be reached by sea tractor at high tide, is returning with a raft of safety measures. The opening hours of the Grand Ballroom restaurant have been extended to ensure social distancing and all guests will be required to fill in a pre-arrival questionnaire.Buffet breakfasts have been scrapped in favour of à la carte options and there will be an increased emphasis on outdoor activities such as fly fishing. However, guests will have to wait to enjoy the hotel’s popular Agatha Christie-inspired murder mystery parties, which are not set to return until November. Here are the key dates for hotel reopenings across the UK.New Yorkers will be able to swim at the city's beaches from July 1, the city's mayor confirmed on Tuesday.“The rumors are true: NYC beaches will open for swimming on July 1,” tweeted mayor Bill de Blasio. He added that social distancing rules should be followed and that beachgoers should cover their faces.Beaches in a few states were partially reopened for the country's Memorial Day holiday weekend of May 23-25, with various restrictions, including a swimming ban at New York City beaches.Read our latest advice on travel to the US.Zanzibar has nothing on Britain’s own Cote d’Azur, writes Brian Jackman. Growing up in suburban Surrey after the war, I knew there was a wilder world out there beyond the surrounding sea of rooftops. A world where palm trees whispered in the breeze and basking sharks cruised beneath the cliffs in waters bluer than the Caribbean.This I had discovered because my father worked for the Southern Railway. Every year he was given privilege tickets which allowed him to take us on holiday anywhere in Britain at no expense. So, while my childhood friends spent their summers at easy-to-reach South Coast resorts like Bognor and Littlehampton – this was long before the advent of package tours and cheap flights, when the Mediterranean was still a rich man’s playground – we travelled by steam train down to Britain’s own Cote d’Azur: Cornwall. Read the full story.Merlin Entertainments has said it will reopen all its major theme parks, attractions and accommodation across England from July 4 for day visits and short breaks.  Alton Towers, Thorpe Park, Legoland Windsor, Warwick Castle and Chessington World of Adventures Resort are among Merlin’s holdings. Its indoor attractions, including the Blackpool Tower, Sea Life Centres and Madame Tussaud’s, will also reopen on June 4 in line with the latest Government guidelines.  Alton Towers and Warwick began welcoming visitors on June 6, while Chessington's zoo area resumed business on June 18.   Tickets must be booked online and numbers will be reduced in accordance with reduced capacity. Other safety measures include new queuing formats, PPE for staff and enhanced cleaning procedures.Here's everything we know about UK holidays this summer.The islands of Madeira and Porto Santo plan to welcome back foreign visitors from July 1 and have released details of the safety measures travellers can expect, including in airports and hotels.Visitors advised to complete Covid-19 test within 72 hours of arrivalMandatory use of face masksSocial distancing in place throughoutFree test on arrival at the airport (for those not tested beforehand)Passengers will be informed by phone of results within 12 hours (confinement is not mandatory during waiting time)Those who test positive, and their direct contacts, will be subject to confinement at a designated hotel (all costs will be paid by local authorities) after seven days passengers will be subject to new testsSocial distancing at check-in and in common areasMandatory use of face masks for guests and staff in public areasRoom capacity limited to two people, except for families with children up to 12 years oldCovid-19 kits available in all roomsSwimming pools, spas, saunas and hot tubs limited to 50 per cent capacityPortugal has already opened to international travellers. Read our latest advice on visiting Portugal.With cruise lines keeping tight-lipped about potential sailings this summer – including voyages around the British Isles – there remains another way to safely get back on the water, reports Benjamin Parker.Following the Prime Minister’s announcement yesterday, hotel boats and holiday boat hire has been given the go-ahead in England from July 4, with other regions of the UK set to follow during July.Harry Theochari, chair of Maritime UK, said:We are delighted to see that the holiday hire boat industry can re-open from July 4, including the booking of overnight stays on boats. Britain absolutely needs a break and this will provide a real boost to morale for millions of people. However, we cannot underestimate the challenge that lies ahead for large parts of the economy, maritime included. Just take the cruise industry - which supports thousands of jobs in coastal communities - they haven’t been able to earn a penny since lockdown. As we ease restrictions, it's crucial that those sectors that can help deliver balanced, regional growth, like maritime, are supported as a priority.The city's Liceu opera house reopened to a hall of potted plants on Monday, following a three-month closure. A string quartet performed Puccini’s 1890 movement Crisantemi (Chrysanthemums) to 2,292 plants.  Artist Eugenio Ampudia came up with the idea as a way to examine our relationship with nature and the impact the lockdown has had on public spaces. The performance was also broadcast online.The Uceli Quartet perform to an audience of plantsBookings surged for one of Britain's major holiday park operators after Prime Minister Boris Johnson's announcement yesterday that caravan parks, campsites and self-catering accommodation can reopen in England from July 4.Within an hour of the PM's announcement, our bookings began to soar, and by mid-afternoon we'd recorded the highest number of holidays ever booked in a single day, said Tony Clish, director of Park Holidays UK. The group, which has 31 centres, said that even with social distancing in place it can accommodate over 10,000 people every night. Behind-the-scenes preparations for re-opening have been going on for weeks, said Mr Clish, and are designed to ensure maximum peace of mind for guests.Planned health and safety measures include eliminating physical contact with staff at check-ins, ensuring all workers wear PPE when appropriate and that they are temperature checked on their arrival at work each day. Hand sanitising stations will be available across the sites and holiday homes will be deep-cleaned between visits.Astoria, Astor, Columbus and Vasco de Gama, which are anchored at Tilbury Docks in Essex, have all been detained while Marco Polo at Avonmouth Docks in Bristol has also been held following an inspection amid reports of expired contracts and late pay, reports Kaye Holland.A sixth ship, Magellan, was inspected but not detained.Following its inspections, the MCA said: “Surveyors found a number of expired and invalid seafarers employment agreements, late payment of wages and crews who had been on board for over 12 months. All these are in breach of the Maritime Labour Convention and the ships have been detained for that reason.”All five ships belong to Athens-based Global Cruise Lines Limited but are operated by British firm Cruise &amp Maritime Voyages (CMV). The vessels were in the middle of cruises when the outbreak of the coronavirus forced them to sail back to the UK.Read the full storyHere were the biggest stories from Tuesday: Hotels, pubs, title: pound sterling developing country currency brexit
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘We believe sterling is in the process of evolving into a currency that resembles the underlying reality of the British economy: small and shrinking,’&nbspsay Bank of America currency analystsThe Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.The pound sterling has behaved more like the volatile currency of a developing country over the past four years since the Brexit referendum vote, according to an analysis by foreign exchange traders.Since the Brexit vote on 23 June 2016 the pound has suffered a record fall against the dollar, a rapid gain and then another precipitous slide to its weakest level in 35 years.The price swings of the currency have been notable, but Kamal Sharma and Myria Kyriacou of Bank of America also note that the “liquidity” of the currency – the difference between the rates at which traders are willing to buy and sell – seems worse than for other major currencies and that traders are also pricing in a higher risk of future volatility.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesWhat really forces currency markets and exchange rates to change?Their research also suggests that during the coronavirus crisis only the Brazilian real has seen more volatility in foreign exchange futures markets than sterling.This has led them to argue that the UK’s currency should best be seen as an emerging market (EM) currency – such as South Africa’s rand or Turkey’s lira – rather than compared to traditional peers such as the US dollar or the euro or other members of the G10 group of industrialised economies.“A more bespoke view of the pound is required and one that would take an EM-esque view.”The Bank of America analysts are clear that the volatility of sterling in recent years has been largely driven by the result of the Brexit vote and they warn that this is likely to intensify, rather than fall away, as the UK formally leaves the bloc, with or without a trade deal, next year.“Brexit is likely to permanently alter the way in which investors view the pound,” they say.They also see the fiscal and economic fallout of the coronavirus crisis in the UK influencing the way the currency is traded.They see the government’s fiscal deficit at 6 per cent of GDP in 2021 and the current account – the amount the country as a whole borrows from abroad – at 4 per cent. This would put the UK’s “dual deficit” – a combination of the two measures – higher than the G20 average and also wider than that of South Africa and Turkey.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. sterling could well fall further if EU trade talks falter.Sterling suffered a record one-day plunge against the dollar on the night of 23 June 2016 when a majority in the country unexpectedly voted to leave the European Union.Before the vote it was trading at around $1.45, but had swung to just $1.22 by the end of the year.Most analysts ascribed that huge price move to expectations from traders and investors that the UK economy would be permanently smaller as a result of leaving the EU single market and customs union.In the following years sterling bounced up to a peak of $1.42 in 2018 as
