title: how london could look european style plans outside drinking
story: Covent Garden, Soho, Chinatown, Mayfair and Oxford Street are on course for a dramatic redesign to help visitors flock back to the capital and start spending again over the next few months.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesCafes, bars and restaurants will be given permission to put tables and chairs outside for a temporary period - with road closures and pavements made wider to make room.Applications for outdoor seating can be turned around in just a few days, the council claims.Covent Garden road closures will be put in place from am to pm, and in Soho from pm to pm during the week and from noon to pm on Saturdays.Greek Street, Frith Street, Dean Street and several others in Soho will be closed to cars - along with Haymarket, Jermyn Street and Baker Street.The  proposals are being brought forward by Westminster City Council.Manchester is also considering usingsimilar temporary rules to reawaken its nightle.The makeover it set to be in place as pubs and restaurants open their doors to the public once again from July  - as announced by the PM yesterday.But they wont allow customers to stand up and drink outside - as the council thinks it will break social distancing guidelines.It meansyou dont have a table booked at your local pub or restaurant, you may be turned away.Their guidance says: Pubs and bars will also need to ensure they have a license for tables and chairsthey wish to have patrons outside of theirvenue, and again premises may only operate with table service.Unfortunately, we cannot allow vertical drinking and drinking outside venues as we believe this will lead to acontravention of the government guidance on social distancingand could cause signicant harm to local residential amenity.The council also says that pubs and restaurants should open up their toilets for people to use safely, too.Cllr Rachael Robathan, leader of Westminster City Council, said: “The hospitality sector is vital to Westminster’s economy with more than , bars and restaurants. They, and our many other attractions, are the reason people fly thousands of miles to enjoy the West End.“So we are doing what we can to support our hospitality business through the vital summer months and into the autumn. The residents’ groups we have spoken to have been very supportive as they know this is a temporary measure for the benefit of all of Westminster.“The West End in particular is a unique global draw, and I am confident we can give it and our other famous locations a continental sheen that visitors, residents and regulars alike will enjoy.”Kate Nicholls, of UK Hospitality, said: “We are going to need a dynamic and supportive approach to reopening hospitality businesses and Westminster council is showing positivity in its plans to get businesses back up and running.”The news in Westminster comes as the Government is set to bring in new planning and licensing laws to help businesses to cope.Legislation to be pushed through Parliament starting this week will allow pubs temporary permission to transform car parks and other outdoor spaces into dining areas without permission, too.Today new guidance for pubs and restaurants was revealed, meaning people will have a very dferent experience when they go out from July .Live music will be banned, along with showing anything on screens which encourages people to shout.So it looks like football matches will be off for now - alongside other sports games.Dancing will also be not allowed, and people will have to leave their contact details with the venue for  days in case of an outbreak.The new measures come into effect on England on July , but Scotland and Wales have not said they will follow suit yet.JULY th is Independence Day in America – and it’s shaping up that way too in Westminster.Across the City, my council is responsible for , licensed bars, restaurants and cafes. They are part of the tourist offer that draws visitors from across the world, and why people enjoy a night in the West End.My council has taken the pioneering step of announcing that we will allow dozens of streets to become temporary outdoor restaurants with tables and chairs. It means more choice in those busy areas like Soho, Covent Garden and Chinatown.Equally importantly, it will help to keep people in jobs. The hospitality industry is a major employer, and we all know how tough it has been for workers while the shutters have been down.Now, we could all make jokes about the famous British weather and weather al fresco dining will work here in the way it does in Dubai or Malaga. title: 12 arm band eases hay fever misery sells out 3 hours pollen bomb explodes
story: Brits are set to be hit with a pollen bomb this week and many have been left wondering how they will stop their symptoms from becoming unbearable.Those who suffer from allergies have said the Qu-Chi band could be the answer.Today the majority of the country will experience very high levels of pollen, with Grampian having high levels and the Highlands having medium levels.People who live in Orkney and Shetland will escape the sneezes as the area has low pollen levels for today.This is while for the rest of the week most of the country will also have very high levels of pollen in the air.The Qu-Chi Hayfever Band cost £. and has been hailed as “amazing” by those who suffer during pollen season.Media personality Jodie Marsh posted a photo of her partner Billy Collins on Instagram where he was wearing the band.As a result the band sold out within just three hours and it is also the th best seller in Amazon’s health and personal care section.The band applies pressure to the LI- point on the elbow known as Quchi.By putting pressure on this part of the body, energy is pulled away from the head, nose, face and throat.This physical pressure can help relieve symptoms related to the nose and throat.It can be worn once symptoms begin andyour symptoms are particularly severe one day then there is a small button you can use to apply extra pressure.It’s drug free and can be used alongside your traditional hay fever medication such as eye drops, antihistamines and nasal sprays.Antihistamines help hay fever sufferers as they block the chemical called histamine in the body.They cause relief from animal, pollen or dust allergies.This is while nasal sprays can be used to treat the cold like symptoms hay fever sufferers experience.Many people who suffer from hay fever will have itchy or red eyes, eye drops can also be used to relieve these symptoms.. AntihistaminesAntihistamine tablets, capsules and sprays can relieve most hay fever symptoms – sneezing, itchy, runny eyes, skin irritation, itchy nose and throat – but are less effective for nasal congestion.Although strong antihistamines can be prescribed by a GP, most people buy antihistamines over the counter in a pharmacy.These usually contain either Cetirizine or Loratadine. If one doesn’t work for you, you can try the other one.Some contain chlorphenamine and these are more liable to make you drowsy. All antihistamines can make you drowsy and it is illegal to drivethey do. It is also dangerous to operate machinery.. Steroid nasal spraysSteroid nasal sprays help reduce inflammation in the nose.They work best for clearing nasal symptoms – itching, sneezing, watering and congestion – although sprays sometimes clear eye symptoms too.Again, look for the active ingredients - beclomethasone, budesonide, fluticasone or mometasone – own brand versions can be cheaper.. Allergen barrier balmsOrganic drug-free allergen barrier balms such as HayMax are applied to the nostrils and bones of the eyes in the morning and throughout the day.They are used to stop allergens from entering the body through the nose.They are especially useful as they can be used immediately, together with other hay fever products and are suitable for children and pregnant and breastfeeding women.”. title: gordon ramsay houses returns london cornwall
story: The TV chef angered his neighbours after moving his family into his £million second home - although friends say he swapped the capital for the beach on March , before Brits could be fined for any non-essential travel.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesHes now travelled the  miles back home for what is believed to be the second time, and was pictured in London yesterday.The chef and restaurateur, , was spotted stepping out of his Range Rover with daughter Holly, .The pair were joined by an aide seen holding a document announcing the reopening of his restaurant Lucky Cat.Eateries will be among the businesses allowed to reopen on July  amid eased lockdown laws.Hishome falls into a grey area of the restrictions.Government officials say Brits currently cant stay away from their home or their support bubble household overnight - including for holidays.Just a few exceptions apply - for example,a person has to stay away for essential work.The legislation isnt specic about ing from a second home to a permanent address.Nevertheless, the move is expected to spark criticism - as its the second time hes believed to have made the journey during lockdown.Gordon also appeared to have made the trip to his Wandsworth townhouse in late May.Currently, Brits cant stay overnight at other properties - with just a few exceptions.The Government says people cant visit friends and family inside their homes - unless theyre part of a support bubble.We also cant stay away from our homes or our support bubble households overnight - including for holidays - except for work purposes or other essential travel.And we cant gather outdoors in a group of more than six - unless exclusively with members of our own households or support bubbles. The journey takes five hours by car.During that apparent visit, he announced the reopening of a restaurant, The Narrow, telling fans on social media it was exciting news.And this time around, the chef donned a blazer before filming a video for his .million Instagram followers in which he announced the opening of Restaurant Gordon Ramsay on Royal Hospital Road in Cha. The caption under the video reads: Exciting news UK... We’re ready to open our doors again on  July. We can’t wait to see you guys ... we’ve missed you!!The notes held by his employee indicate hes also preparing to release a similar video for Lucky Cat by Gordon Ramsay in Grosvenor Square.Gordon made locals furious after relocating to Cornwall as the pandemic took hold in the UK.Last month, he claimed lockdown has been an absolute nightmare for all of us.Despite that, hes been seen out and about on a number of occasions when outings were strictly limited to an hour a day.He was photographed on boat trips and bike rides - even though the Governments advice at the time was to stay at home.Furious locals hit out at the famously poor-tempered star, and one neighbour seethed: Don’t you realise that by doing that you’ve possibly brought the virus with you and because Cornwall is not your main residence If you and your family get sick you will place yet more strain on an already fragile infrastructure.Gordonshome comes as it was revealed he has taken out loans to shore up his restaurant empire which has been shuttered by the coronavirus lockdown.He has registered charges with Barclays against  companies, which includes those managing some of his Michelin star outlets.Gordon and we Tana, who married in , have five children – Megan, , Matilda, , twins Jack and Holly,  and one-year-old Oscar James.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new study reveals eight in ten brits feel they settled for their partner
story: A study of , adults found a ‘guess that will do’ approach has been adopted because they either haven’t been able to afford better, or get what they really want. Incredibly,  per cent of adults have found themselves in a relationship with someone they didn’t think was ‘the one’ – with  per cent doing so because they didn’t want to be left on the shelf and  per cent worrying they’d never find love.And seven in ten adults have at some point accepted a salary which was far from ideal, with a fth feeling there wasn’t room for negotiation and one quarter hoping a pay rise might happen in the future.Of those polled,  per cent have also accepted a job they didn’t want, largely because they couldn’t find anything better.A spokeswoman for Lottoland, which carried out the research in connection with their new Lotto Plus Multiple Millionaires Bonus draw, said: “We know that people often want more out of le, and as such strive to do better, but the findings do indicate an acceptance that things can’t always be perfect.“However, there should be some areas of le where you don’t settle for second best.It is human nature to want more – more fun, more spontaneity, and more choice – and that’s why we’re introducing more choice and more opportunities for our own customers.”The study also found a house, friendships, and a car are among the other le changing things adults have settled for, when they really didn’t want to.Almost two third of adults have ended up moving into a house which wasn’t their dream home, with money the chief factor.And  per cent have found themselves in unhealthy friendships, with confidence cited as the main reason for not pursuing alternative relationships.But when it comes to settling in le, not all decisions are le changing.Nearly four in  adults have had to settle on a supermarket’s own brand of food over something posher, while  per cent have made do with a cheap restaurant rather than opting for fine dining.Choosing a slice of cake smaller than one would like, and deciding on the house wine over something a little more refined also feature in the top  list.Furniture for the home, haircuts, shoes and gts are also among the things Brits have chosen, despite wanting better.It also emerged three in  have settled for the price of something rather than negotiating, and  per cent have resigned themselves to working long hours instead of meeting up with friends.. Salary. Job. Dream house. Car. Friendships. Partner. Supermarkets own food instead of branded. A cheaper restaurant over fine dining. Staying at home for the evening instead of going out with. Clothing brands. The price of something rather than negotiating. A gt for someone. Mobile phone   smart phone. Area you live in. House wine instead of the higher cost option. A self-catered holiday over a luxurious all inclusive. Furniture. Haircut. Shoes. Working longer hours instead of spending time with friends. Having a small slice of cake instead of a massive one. Clothes a size larger than youd like to be buying. Coffee - getting instant instead of the good stuff. TV. Decor. The cost of utility bills. Cheap beers. Who to socialise with. Handbags. Fitness gear Holidays, the area to live in, smart phones, and coffee also feature in the list as those things where sometimes, second best will have to do.But researchers from OnePoll found two thirds of those polled DO want more out of le, and the same percentage say the older they get, the less likely they are to settle for anything less than perfect.Four in  adults will only settle on somethingthey really don’t have a choice, and  per cent said money is always the decisive factor.Being too relaxed, lacking confidence, and wanting to go with the flow are also reasons why Brits don’t push to get what they want all the time.Butthey had the choice and felt able,  per cent would like to improve their financial situation, while  per cent want a better salary.One fth of adults would like to improve their relationships, and one third want to live somewhere nicer both in terms of house, and location.A spokeswoman for Lottoland added: “As a nation we’re go-getters, and striving to do better is part of who we are.Lottoland wants to mirror that by offering playing more chances to win, more flexibility and more enjoyment along the way.“In the spirit of offering more, we’re launching a special promotion for Lotto Plus players – the Multiple Millionaires Bonus Draw. title: new pub rules coronavirus
story: Strict guidance tells pub and restaurant owners to prevent interaction between people in their venues - including clamping down on live music and ordering food and drinks through an app. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesGovernment guidance has laid out plans for pubs to reopen without transmission of coronavirus soaring. The PM said yesterday he was looking forward to the bustle toto Britains streets as he announced most businesses would be able to reopen. Mr Johnson told the House of Commons: We will also re-open restaurants and pubs.    But he warned: All hospitality indoors will be limited to table-service, and our guidance will encourage minimal staff and customer contact.The PM has refused to rule out bringing back a national lockdowncoronavirus cases start to rise again - so restaurants and pubs will have to follow strict rules to make sure people stick to social distancing. The days of crowding around bars waiting to order are over in a new normal of pub visits. Venues and being encouraged to be table-service only, and have guests order drinks and food through an app where possible.The guidance said: Indoor table service must be used where possible. Outdoor table service should also be encouraged though customers are permitted to stand outsidedistanced appropriately. The guidelines do not rule out ordering from the bar entirely, but warns venues should prevent customers from remaining at the bar or counter after ordering. Pubs have been told to encourage the use of contactless ordering from tables where available - for example, through an ordering app. The new rules mean people wont be able to hang out at the bar after theyve ordered, and will have to find a table or stand outside. All meetings indoors must only be with no more than two households at a time. Staff could also radio orders through to the kitchens to reduce movement by discouraging non-essential trips within venues. While both pubs and sports matches will have ed, Brits wont be able to do both at the same time. To discourage large groups of people coming together and yelling at TV screens or each other, broadcasts have been banned. Loud music will also be banned to stop people having to shout to be heard by their friends.The guidance says venues should ensure that steps are taken to avoid people needing to unduly raise their voices to each other. This includes but is not limited to, refraining from playing music or broadcasts that may encourage shouting, includingplayed at a volume that makes normal conversation dficult. This is because of the potential for increased risk of transmission, particularly from aerosol transmission.Live music and performances wont be allowed to continue under the new plans. The guidance warns venues they should not permit live performances, including drama, comedy and music, to take place in front of a live audience. Singing is a particular concerns - as droplets potentially carrying coronavirus could travel further as pub goers belt out their favourite songs.Dancing is also out, pubs have been told totake steps to prevent other close contact activities such as communal dancing. Venues are being encouraged to use disposable condiment packets where possible to limit the spread of germs via surfaces.Otherwise bottles need to be cleaned thoroughly after each use. Cutlery wont be laid out on tables unless people order food either. The guidance says venues should minimise customer self service of food, cutlery and condiments to reduce the risk of transmission. For example, providing cutlery and condiments only when food is served.The guidance says businesses should help the NHS Test and Trace system by keeping a registry of patrons contact details for at least  days in case of an outbreak. Venues are told to assistby keeping a temporary record of your customers and visitors for  days, in a way that is manageable for your business, and assist NHS Test and Trace with requests for that dataneeded. This could help contain clusters or outbreaks. Many businesses that take bookings already have systems for recording their customers and visitors – including restaurants, hotels, and hair salons. If you do not already do this, you should do so to help fight the virus.If there is an outbreak, it will allow contact tracers to easily find out who was in a pub or restaurant at a particular time. Pubs and restaurants will have to reduce the number of people in venues at any one time to allow for social distancing - but also to discourage public transport use. The new rules will ban groups of more than  people to form. That means evenvenues can have  people  metres apart they wont be able to.The guidance says: Evenit is possible to safely seat a number of people inside a venue, it may not be safe for them all to travel or enter that venue. Venues in nearby areas will have to work together to stagger arrival and departure times to avoid massive queues forming close to each other. Toilets which have been closed throughout the coronavirus crisis will reopen in pubs, restaurants and public places.But they will have to be subject to strict hygiene restrictions and extra cleaning. title: uk weather forecast heatwave step national emergency
story: Forecasters have raised a heat health alert to amber for the East and West Midlands and told people to look out for the vulnerable, elderly and babies.The level three warning is triggered when temperatures are recorded that could have a “signicant effect on health”reached for two consecutive days and the intervening night.In the Midlands, conditions are forecast to see highs of C during the day and C at night.However,temperatures continue to rise the Met Office will place a National Emergency red warningIts website explains: “This is where a heatwave is so severe and or prolonged that its effects extend outside the health and social care system.”Adding: “At this level, illness and death may occur among the fit and healthy, and not just in high-risk groups.”It comes as medics warn that the heatwave will bring exceptionally high UV levels.Temperatures are tipped to rocket towards C tomorrow as the UK continues to bask in warm weather.Brits spent yesterday flocking to the country’s beaches, as they celebrated Boris Johnson’s reopening Britain’s pubs, bars and restaurants in July.But this has led to forecasters and medics to tell people to take extra precautions to stay safe in the sunMet Office meteorologist Alex Burkill said that UV levels will be reaching eight across many places and will be reaching nine across parts of Devon and Cornwall tomorrow.Thats about as high as it gets really in the UK. The sun is as strong as it gets at the moment because were so close to the solstice.Weve got peak sun strength, clear skies, plenty of sunshine - theyre the perfect ingredients for high UV.Mr Burkill advised anyone spending time outside on Wednesday and Thursday to protect themselves.Shoppers have also been warned they could be forced to spend extra time in the sun as a result of social-distancing measures.Dr Lynn Thomas, medical director at St John Ambulance, said: You could end up in the sun for longer than expected on what would normally be a quick journey, such as queuing to enter the supermarket, so you should be prepared to look after yourself and others.She added: Heat exhaustion and heatstroke are two of the most serious problems that can develop when the mercury soars but by being prepared you can spot the early warning signs, such as headache and dizziness.Public Health England has also issued a warning telling those with health conditions, coronavirus shielders, elderly people and very young children to be careful in the heat.Public health consultant Emer OConnell said vulnerable people should be checked up on regularly.The most important advice is to ensure they stay hydrated, keep cool and know how to keep their homes cool.You will need to do things dferently this year, for example keeping in touch by phone. If you need to provide direct care to someone at risk from hot weather, follow government guidance on how to do this safely, she said.

title: royal navy first ever crewless boat pacific 24
story: More than £million has been spent on the Pacic  boat and other self-operated crafts.The boats could help operations including search-and-rescue and drug raids in the Caribbean and Middle East. Boats could be sent on inidual missions or in groups, reaching speeds of up to  knots . In pursuit mode, it has a range of  nautical miles. The Pacic  has been used in sea boat operations from Royal Navy warships for more than  years.But the new drone version of the boat could provide a more streamlined way of carrying out its wide range of operations - and even open up some new types of missions.The boats will be controlled from a parent ship, such as a frigate or destroyer.Defence Minister Jeremy Quin said: Commencing the trials of the crewless Pacic  boat is an important stepping stone in the Royal Navys development of its autonomous capability to ensure our fleet remains at the forefront of military innovation and technology, ready to meet the evolving threats of modern warfare.The crewless Pacic  is sponsored by NavyX, the specialist wing of the Royal Navy which trials cutting-edge technology for use on the front line.The team has worked in partnership with BAE Systems, which builds the Pacic  in Portsmouth, to commission the new boat.A prototype, controlled from the frigate HMS Argyll, debuted at the DSEI defence technology showcase in London last September, since when BAE and the Navy have pressed ahead with a working model fit for the front line.The vessels control system and sensors mean a sailor should be able to give the unmanned craft generic tasking, and the boat will decide for itself how it carries out that task.Lieutenant Commander Rob Manson of the NavyX team said: The autonomous nature of this craft adds huge capability and flexibility.Brooke Hoskins, Products and Training Services Director at BAE Systems said: We are proud to support the Royal Navys autonomous requirements, which includes increasing its operational effectiveness whilst reducing the burden on, or threat to, its sailors.Trials with the new craft begin this month, followed by trials with a Royal Navy warship later this year which should determine whether the UK invests in a fleet of such craft or just a few for specic missions.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leicester city demarai gray girlfriend mansion raid worcestershire
story: The raid at the Premier League players mansion in Worcestershire was part of a six-month crime spree.Grays girlfriend Emma Hickman was confronted by balaclava-clad intruders, one wielding a machete, as she lay in bed naked with the couples six-week-old child.She was so terried she later moved out.Aaron Jones, , and Tyler Greenway, , were both found guilty of conspiracy to rob following a trial.Jones was also convicted of conspiracy to possess a firearm.They had both previously admitted conspiracy to burgle and theft.Nicholas Rothero, , and his son Cory Rothero, , had both previouslyadmitted conspiracy to rob, steal, burgle, and conspiracy to possess afirearm.Darren Sadler, , of Bartley Green, had previously pleaded guilty to conspiracy to rob.Jones was jailed for  years, Nicholas Rothero for  years andSaddler for four years.Saddlers sentence was ordered to run consecutively to a term of tenyears and eight months he is already serving for robbery.Both Cory Rothero and Greenway were each sentenced to  years in ayoung offenders institution.Michael Duck QC, prosecuting, told Birmingham Crown Court: Thedefendants are a group of organised criminals. Between October and April  they committed a series of armed robberies andburglaries at commercial and residential premises.He said they used serious violence which escalated over time.They went to signicant s to disguise themselves and chosevulnerable targets such as small stores which had a limited amount ofstaff, Mr Duck said.They arrived in stolen cars which were used to get away at the fastest speed possible.Mr Duck said: They arrived mob-handed, conspicuously armed withknives, making a lot of noise and terrying those they encountered.They raided safes and cashpoints.The first shop targeted was a One Stop in Bristol Road North,Northfield, on October . They made off with £, after wielding ahammer, kne and crow bar and workers to the back of the premises.The gang also netted arond £, after terrorising two employees atthe Barnt Green Inn pubb and snatched £,-worth of mobiles from aphone shop where staff were threatened.Saddler was arrested following a struggle with police after a raid ona Car Phone Warehouse.But that did not deter the close knit team, who attacked a TescoExpress in Northfield armed themselves with weapons including a gun.Describing the attack on the home of the -year-old footballer, Mr Duck said there was evidence that the premises had been deliberately targeted.He went on: The male occupant of the premises was not there that day.He was at work.Members of the gang, armed with knives, parked alongside a hedgebefore breaking in.They stayed briefly downstairs before going upstairs where -year-oldMiss Hickman was trying to catch up on some sleep.She was woken from her sleep and greeted by the sight of a man whowas obviously masked and carrying a large black kne, Mr Duck said.The intruder, Nicholas Rothero, was then joined by Jones and CoryRothero and one of them picked up a gold kne from the side of the bedwhich her partner used to open parcels and envelopes.She was completely trapped and confined with the confines of her bedroom.Mr Duck said they knew something about her boyfriend and expressedsurprise he was not there.During the trial, Miss Hickman said the raiders demanded jewellery and money.She said she had been petried and they had accused her partner ofbeing a gangbanger and demanded to know when he was coming back.They snatched her Rolex and told her the footballer could fork out foranother one.When she told them her mother was on the way, the men told her hershed get hurt when she arrived.The raiders also took keys to Gray’s Mercedes only to discover it wasnot on the driveway before they fled with £,-worth of cash andjewellery in a stolen car.Passing sentence, Judge Richard Bond said the offences were executedruthlessly and with a real degree of success.He said that on two occasions guns were used to instil fear intovictims so they would co-operate.A feature is the professionalism in the way the offending was carriedout, he told the gangsters.Full disguises were used by the offenders to cause victims to beintimidated when confronted by you.Victims were made to feel scared and helpless and on some occasionsfearful for their lives.Your professionalism was also demonstrated by the speed of the offences.You targeted vulnerable premises. The sophistication of youroffending was also demonstrated by the wearing of gloves to ensurethat finger prints were not left behind.CCTV shows on several occasions members of staff cowering in terrorduring the course of robberies.Referring to the attack on Grays home, he said: This property wasdeliberately targeted by you because of who lived there.Jones made inquiries on the internet about the person.You believed there would be rich pickings at the property. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHairdressers, barber shops and other beauty studios will reopen in England on July  after more than three months of lockdown. People will finally be able to get a professional haircut for the first time since March and hairdressers are expected to be in high demand. But things will look very, very dferent to how they were before - starting with your hairdresser wearing a big plastic visor over their face. There will be screens between tills and between many chairs doors and windows will be kept open to increase ventilation and you should turn up alone. Walk-ins will be banned, gowns made disposable and while talking is allowed, raising your voice is not. Here are  ways getting a haircut will be very dferent from July . The guidance admits itaposs clearly not possible to maintain social distancing when cutting someoneaposs hair - and that means wearing a visor. This is a clear visor that covers the face and provides a barrier between the wearer and the client from respiratory droplets caused by sneezing, coughing or speaking. Visors must fit the user and be worn properly. It should cover the forehead, extend below the chin, and wrap around the side of the face. These are a bigger deal than simple face coverings - which are not recommended in hairdressers. Nor is any other extra PPE recommended. Hairdressers should go into isolationtheyaposre told to by Test and Trace, eventheyaposre wearing a visor. . There may be a screen between each chair  Hairdressers are advised to follow social distancing rules - keep people two metres apart, or one metre with mitigations when m isnapost possible. But thereaposs an extra rule - theyaposre also asked to create a physical barrier between workstations, where this is practical. That doesnapost mean a screen between hairdressers and their clients - it means a screen between each chair. . The same hairdressers should keep working side by side The guidance says there should be a consistent pairing system, defined as fixing which workers work together,workers have to be in close proximit. Close proximity means being within arm’s- of someone  for a sustained period of time. . Youaposll get a health screening before you come in  The guidance says COVID- related screening questions should be asked of clients ahead of their appointment. The questions are:Have you had the recent onset of a new continuous cough  Do you have a high temperature  Have you noticed a loss of, or change in, normal sense of taste or smell If the client has any of these symptoms, however mild, they should stay at home and reschedule their appointment, the guidance says.  . Disposable gowns - and a washing regime between each appointment Hairdressers are advised to use disposable gowns for each client. Where this is not possible, they should use separate gowns and towns each client, washing between use. Hairdressers and beauty salons should also sanitise any reusable equipment, including client chairs, treatment beds, and scissors, after each appointment, and at the start and end of shts. . You can talk - but not shout, and not listen to loud music  The guidance says hairdressers should ensure steps are taken to avoid people needing to unduly raise their voices to each other. This includes refraining from playing music or broadcasts loud enough to encourage shouting. . You canapost get a haircut unless you book The guidance recommends operating an appointment-only system. That means no walk-ins. People are also being urged to turn up to their appointment on time. Venues should avoid overrunning or overlapping appointments.  . You may have to queue outside Hairdressers are told to use outside spaces for queuing where available and safe, for example some car parks. People can wait in waiting areasthereaposs sufficient social distancing, butthere isnapost, venues should consider moving to a ‘one-in-one-out’ policy.The guidance suggests contacting clients virtually to let them know when they are ready to be seen. . You shouldnapost take your spouse or kids The guidance says: When booking an appointment, ask the clientthey can attend on their own, where possible. Those with children will be reminded they are responsible for supervising them at all times and should follow social distancing guidelines.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailLoud football match screenings or music, dance floors, ketchup bottles and even sheltering from the rain are set to be banned when Englandaposs pubs reopen on July . Government guidance today shows many toilets will need to be one-in, one-out and bar staff hidden behind screens to prevent the spread of the virus. Pubs will be told to keep lists of everyone who comes in for  days in case there is an outbreak - with more outdoor seats and tape to mark distance on the floor. Bar managers will be told to work with their rivals on the same street to make sure they stagger their opening times. And punters will be warned they canapost shelter insidea rainstorm - otherwise they could cause an outbreak. We knew a lot of the restrictions already. For example, you can only sit indoors with one other household - socially distanced. If youaposre in the beer garden, you can sit in a group of up to six - socially distanced - or in a group of two households of any size. Now the governmentaposs guidance shows just how dferent the new normal will be to le before. Here are  key ways itaposll change your experience of the pub. . Loud music or broadcasts will be banned to stop people shouting  Loud music or loud broadcasts like football will be banned to stop people shouting at each other. The guidance says all venues should ensure that steps are taken to avoid people needing to unduly raise their voices to each other. This includes, but is not limited to, refraining from playing music or broadcasts that may encourage shouting, includingplayed at a volume that makes normal conversation dficult. This is because of the potential for increased risk of transmission, particularly from aerosol transmission. It also says loud background music, communal dancing, group singing or chanting should be prevented. . Live music, comedy and dance floors will be banned  The guidance says venues should not permit live performances, including drama, comedy and music, to take place in front of a live audience. This is to stop aerosol transmission - from either the performer or their audience. Theatres are likewise allowed to open but onlythey donapost put on a live show. Dance floors in pubs and bars are also banned. You should take steps to prevent close contact activities, such as communal dancing, the guidance says. . Ketchup bottles and cutlery are banished from tables  The guidance says pubs and restaurants should provide cutlery and condiments only when food is served. And the days of the communal ketchup or mayonnaise bottle are numbered - as pubs and restaurants should provide only disposable condiments. Communal bottles are allowed but onlythey are cleaned after every single use. . Everyone has to give their name to staff - and itaposs kept for  days  All pubs, bars, restaurants and more are being told to assist with the NHS Test and Trace programme. That means keeping a temporary record of your customers and visitors for  days. The guidance doesnapost say how this should be done but lists visitor books or bookings records. Pubs will need to assist NHS Test and Trace with requests for that dataneeded in order to contain clusters or outbreaks. . Bar staff will stand behind screens  The guidance recommends using screens or barriers to separate workers from each other, and from customers at points of service. That could mean bar staff serving from behind a perspex screen to avoid transmission. Staff are also asked to use back-to-back or side-to-side working possible. And staff rotas will need to be redrawn so each person only has contact with a fixed number of others on their team. Tables will be spaced further apart and floor tape or paint will be used to mark areas to help people comply with social distancing. They should be two metres apart - or one metrethere is risk mitigation in place like screens, back-to-back seating or face coverings. . Some toilets will be one-in, one-out  The guidance recommends one way flow systems to stop people bunching up - such as using one door as an entry and one as an exit. Pubs should also arrange one-way travel routes between transport hubs and venues, it says. But thataposs a problem when it comes to pub toilets, many of which are cramped with narrow entrances. On toilets, the guidance urges pubs to use a limited entry approach, with one in, one out. . Youaposll get more outdoor seats, table service - and use apps to order your drinks  Pubs are being encouraged to put in more outdoor seats - with changes coming down the track to let them use car parks as beer gardens. Outdoor table service should also be encouraged, the guidance says - and table service should be followed as a rule to stop people queues. Where bar or counter service is unavoidable, people should be stopped from staying at the bar or counter after ordering, or leaning on it. Pubs are also told to encourage use of contactless ordering from tables where available - for example, through an ordering app. . Staff could radio food orders through to the kitchen Staff are told to reduce movement by discouraging non-essential trips within venues. That could mean restricting access to some areas, encouraging use of radios, telephones or other electronic devices when sending orders from service areas to kitchens, where permitted. The radios would have to be cleaned between use. . Youaposll be banned from propping up the bar - or sheltering from the rain  Pubs are warned they have to plan for keeping the -metre or aposone metre plusapos rules eventhere is a thunderstorm. They need to be clear that customers cannot seek shelter indoors unless social distancing can be maintained. . Indoor spaces will have to be massively below capacity  Sitting indoors will be allowed - but numbers are strictly limited. New coronavirus laws from July  in England will make it illegal for groups of more than  people to form. Pubs, restaurants, cinemas and other venues will be exempt from the aposgroup of apos law, which exists mainly to prevent things like raves. But even so, the guidance warns pubs may have to lower capacity even further than it would bethey had all tables two metres apart. The guidance explains: Evenit is possible to safely seat a number of people inside a venue, it may not be safe for them all to travel or enter that venue. . Youaposll see this sign in the window  Pubs should work with their customers to tell them about the restrictions on gatherings. That means not gathering indoors with more than one other household. And it means not gathering outdoors with more than either one other household, or six people in total from any number of households. In , firms should also display a notication in a prominent place to show a risk assessment has been carried out and theyaposre following the rules. A picture of the notice is above. . Nearby pubs must work together to open at dferent times Inidual businesses should consider the cumulative impact of many venues re-opening in a small area. This means working with local authorities, neighbouring businesses and travel operators to assess this risk and applying additional mitigations. This might have to include staggering entry times with other venues and taking steps to avoid queues building up in surrounding areas.

title: lockdown over pandemic not winter
story: NewsopinionLockdown is over, but the pandemic is not. Winter is coming for Boris JohnsonThe PMs worried about his career, which hangs on how much worse his crisis gets. Living or dying is going to be up to usShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JUN Newsopinion" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWe will not see the likes of lockdown again. Next time, thereaposll be no furlough. No boost for Universal Credit, no protective arm thrown around us.It wonapost happen, partly, because weaposre bored and wonapost wear another  months of self-incarceration. But it also wonapost happen because we canapost afford to do it twice. The most worrying thing is not just that the government will leave us to weather the storm on our own - itaposs that the government created the storm, put it in the air, and knows full well that rain is on the way.  There are a handful of great positives from the coronavirus pandemic so far. Itaposs infected only % of the UK population the government managed to scale up the NHSapos capacity to deal with it by more than was needed most people who got it survived, without lasting side effects and it hit at the start of summer.From evidence now being gathered and shared by researchers more honest than the Chinese government, the virus expires after minutes in direct sunlight. It does not spread easily outdoors, from hard surfaces, or from person-to-person without sustained, close contact. Itaposs not Novichok.And it is the nature of viruses to get apostiredapos. The more virulent versions kill their hosts, limiting their ability to replicate, and natural selection means that in time only the milder versions survive to spread in the community.  But there is one huge problem, which is that Covid- is new. Its mutation rate is unconfirmed, our immunity to it is close to nil, and while the infection inferno has been reduced to flickering embers, those flames are being fanned by easing the lockdown which got us this far.Covid- deaths in the UK are now at the level they were before lockdown. And that daily number of the dead is STILL  times worse than the total death toll in New Zealand. The lockdown is being lted for political reasons, not scientic ones. Not only will backbenchers and businesses not stand any more, but the government is announcing that people can start doing things they were doing about  weeks ago. Households were already aposbubblingapos. Many were already visiting each otheraposs gardens, or homes. And no-oneaposs bothered staying metres apart for more than a month. But some of the new rules do make sense, not least the one about how you can go to church, but not sing. Forcefully propelling air and water droplets at others seems to create the most risk. From South Korea to Bradford, Amsterdam to Washington, whole choirs have become super-spreaders. And in the UK, even in the height of summer, we have had outbreaks in meat processing factories - noisy places where staff have to shout to be heard, stand close to each other on production lines, and temperatures might be as low as  degrees C. In Texas, Iowa, South Dakota, Germany and Wales, slaughtermen and meat packers are testing positive in huge numbers. You donapost need to be an epidemiologist to realise that colder, shoutier places are going to be safe spaces for coronavirus to spend the summer. And that, come colder weather, it will stage a break-out. But the Prime Minister does not seem too concerned, publicly, about whataposs coming down the track. His ministers are making baseless claims for testing that no-one can prove, belittling student nurses, and making a fuss about how going to the pub will save us all. Itaposs time to move on, apparently, even though what comes next could well be just as bad, or even worse. Winter always sees a rise in respiratory infections, and problems for the NHS. Throw in a new bug only % of us may have some immunity to, and the second wave of deaths may be as disproportionately larger than the first as it was during the  Spanish flu pandemic.Instead we have Johnson claiming his  tests for easing lockdown have been met, when only  of them have been ticked off. And when the World Health Organisationaposs entirely-dferent  tests for easing lockdown are only half-completed.If he were a leader,he were the clever man he pretends to be, andhe had ever been a half-competent journalist, he would be honest, and tell us lockdown can go on no longer, and that we have perhaps four months before the virus s.Hopefully less strong, but with NHS staff who are exhausted, their resources depleted, and a population that has lost thousands of jobs, missed millions of hospital appointments, and learned to distrust this governmentaposs every pronouncement. A good Prime Minister, faced with that, would tell us to squirrel away every penny, build a store cupboard, prepare for what is to come. Remortgage, lose weight, ersy your business, move as much as you can online.

story: NewsStricken theatres and arts venues could get coronavirus bailout, No hintsThe hint at further support came after theatres were told they could reopen in England from July  - but not put on any live showsShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUN NewsWest End Theatres in Shaftesbury Avenue, London " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailStricken theatres could be given a government bailout after they warned they face ruin, No hinted today. Downing Street said the government would discuss what support we could potentially provide as England moves into the next phase of lockdown. However, Boris Johnsonaposs official spokesman did not make clear what that support might be. And it comes a week after Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden already said theatres might get further support. Theatres and concert halls have been told they can reopen in England from July  - but not put on any live shows. Showbiz union Bectu last night warned thousands of people are facing losing their jobs.Chief Philippa Childs said: A comprehensive rescue and recovery package is needed and the Government has failed, once again, to recognise the seriousness of the situation. And the English National Ballet - which has furloughed % of its staff - warned the Christmas ballet season is in jeopardy unless the government steps in to help. We have no income, said artistic director Tamara Rojo. Unless something happens soon, there will be no Christmas shows - Christmas will have to be cancelled. The Financial Times reported discussions on a bailout for the arts sector were under way but a decision is not imminent.  Today the PMaposs spokesman said further help was being considered. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBoris Johnsonaposs Government has been urged to prepare for a second wave of coronavirus after it was accused of missteps and not taking the initial outbreak seriously enough. Britainaposs leading medical experts have written an open letter calling for an urgent review of whether the country is properly prepared for the real risk of another fight against Covid-. Earlier modelling has suggested a new peak could hit after Christmas and kill as many as  people a day. The letter published in the British Medical Journal warns ministers that urgent action is needed to prevent further loss of le and to protect the economy amid growing fears of a renewed outbreak over the winter. The appeal is backed by the presidents of the Royal Colleges of Physicians, Surgeons, GPs and Nursing - as well as the chairman of the British Medical Association. It comes after Boris Johnson announced on Tuesday the biggest easing to date of the coronavirus lockdown in England. The Prime Minister said the two-metre social-distancing rule would be replaced with a one-metre plus rule paving the way for pubs, restaurants, hotels and cinemas to begin reopening from July . In an open letter to the leaders of all the UK political parties published in the British Medical Journal, the health leaders call for a rapid and forward-looking assessment of the state of national preparedness in the event of a renewed flare-up. While the future shape of the pandemic in the UK is hard to predict, the available evidence indicates that local flare ups are increasingly likely and a second wave a real risk, they said. Many elements of the infrastructure needed to contain the virus are beginning to be put in place, but substantial challenges remain. The job now is not only to deal urgently with the wide-ranging impacts of the first phase of the pandemic, but to ensure that the country is adequately prepared to contain a second phase. They called for the creation of a cross-party commission with a constructive, non-partisan, four nations approach, to be established to develop practical recommendations for action based on what had been learned so far.  We believe this will be essentialthe UK is to get ahead of the curve, they said. It should focus on those areas of weakness where action is needed urgently to prevent further loss of le and restore the economy as fully and as quickly as possible. We think thereaposs a strong case for an immediate assessment of national preparedness, with the first results available no later than August, and that all its work should be completed by the end of October. Sir Bernard Jenkin, chair of the powerful Liaison Committee apossupergroupapos of MPs, backed calls for a cross-party review. He said: It is essential that the UK is prepared for a second wave of coronavirus later this year. We do not want another Chilcot-type inquiry at this stage, but medics are right to call for a swt cross-party aposlessons learnedapos exercise to be completed by October.This would not only contribute to UKaposs readiness for a new Covid peak but would also strengthen public confidence in the government’s readiness. Ministers have already said that the temporary Nightingale Hospitals set up in case the NHS was overwhelmed by Covid- cases will remain on standby over the coming months.  The letter comes as former chief scientic advisor Sir David King, who now leads the unofficial ‘Independent Sage’ group, told Sky News the lockdown easing is “ extraordinarily risky”. He said lting lockdown too quickly means “the risk of running into a second wave becomes very signicant”. He added: “We must aim to completely get rid of the virus of this country before the winter” “We still see , new cases at least a day in this country. I don’t think there’s anyone who can believe from the scientic point of view that this is a wise move.” Imperial College economist Professor David Miles told BBC Radio  the easing of lockdown measures was overdue. He said: We probably have gone past the point some weeks ago where the benefits of keeping in place the lockdown were large enough to match the rising and enormous costs of lockdown. In other developments: - The Government is providing £ million to help prevent vulnerable people given emergency accommodation during the pandemic being ed to the streets. - Labour is calling for NHS staff to undergo weekly testing for coronavirus in order to ensure waiting list backlogs can be safely cleared. - First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has said the two-metre rule would remain in place in Scotland. Announcing, the easing of the two-metre rule in England, Mr Johnson said the Government was taking a cautious approach and that ministers will not hesitate to apply the brakes in the event of an upsurge in the disease. Want to keep up to date with the latest from Westminster to our newsletter to receive regular news, expert comment and analysis from our Mirror Politics team.  However at the final daily No  briefing, both the Governmentaposs chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance and the chief medical officer for England Professor Chris Whitty stressed it was not a risk-free move. Prof Whitty said it was absolutely critical that people continued to observe social distancing, taking steps to mitigate the spread of the disease when it was not possible to stay two metres apart. He warned the virus was likely to be present in the UK until at least the spring of  and thatpeople ed to their normal patterns of behaviour we will get an uptick for sure. Sir Patrick also warned that despite the falling numbers of people infected with the disease, the threat remained. Donapost be fooled that this means it has gone away. The disease is growing across the world. It is coming down in the UK but it hasnapost gone away, he said.  The easing of the two-metre rule was warmly welcomed by the hospitality sector which had warned that many pubs, cafes and restaurants would be forced to closeit remained in place. Hairdressers, barbers, cinemas, museums and art galleries in England are now also preparing to open their doors to visitors again from July . However close proximity businesses including nightclubs, soft play centres, indoor gyms, nail bars and beauty salons will remain shut, as will bowling alleys and water parks. Professor John Edmunds, who attends Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesmeetings, said the Governmentaposs switch to one metre-plus restrictions could put the country at risk of increased Covid- transmission. The London School of Hygiene  Tropical Medicine academic told BBC Radio aposs Today programme on Wednesday: The easements that are coming are going to have a double effect really because we are going to be allowed to go to pubs and restaurants and so on, and so that will increase our number of contacts.  The easement of the restriction on two metres and allowing people to meet inside is also going to change the nature of the contact to be slightly more risky, so it is likely to have a double effect. There is a risk that transmission will take off again, so we have to be really vigilant, and this is where the Test and Trace system needs to be really working well to make sure we can stamp out any infections that occur. Business Secretary Alok Sharma said protections are in place for staff who feel unsafe while working under the new one metre-plus restrictions when pubs and restaurants open again next month. He told BBC Radio aposs Today programme: There is a legal duty requirement for businesses to keep their workers safe, for those who interact in those businesses to keep them safe. Mr Sharma added: If people are ignoring the rules and they are not keeping a workplace safe, then there are clearly measures that can be followed and it is possible for there to be enforcement notices, there are going to be checks that are carried out, spot checks by the Health and Safety Executive, which they are already doing. And in the case where someone is not following an enforcement order and not fixing things in a workplace, then, for the most serious offences, people can go to prison for up to two years. These are real powers and real teeth that are in place.

Please ask us why.The couple first received an email warning them to remove the sign and when they refused the company followed up with a letter, resulting in the Wrights backing down and taking the sign down hours later, reports said. Mr and Mrs Wright, who live in Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire, now say they were wrong to publicly criticise the Newcastle-based property developer but are still unhappy, according to reports.In an interview with The Sun, Jake said: We backed down because we didnapost want to end up in court.We were being threatened with legal action for being defamatory. Chloe added: Bellway pointed out that signage on walls was breach of our contract which, on reflection, was fair enough. But we’re still not happy. Bellway had said it was working hard to fix the issues the couple have faced and that the sign was breaching “restrictive covenants entered into at the point of sale”. A Bellway Homes spokesman has since said that because the Wrights removed their sign they would not be taking any further action. They said they are in the process of resolving the issues with the garage. Jake and Chloe bought their property in December  but say that since they moved in, it has caused them nothing but problems. After splashing out £, on the house, they realised that the garage kept flooding, with water seeping through the brickwork.  Jake says he reported the issue to Bellway not long after moving in to the property. A contractor visited and seemingly fixed the issue months after they moved in. However, a few weeks later, the couple noticed that the garage was flooded. They asked the developer to fix the issue again.Jake told LeicestershireLive : “Another couple of men came out and said they knew what the issue was and that it was related to the brickwork.“So we let them fix it. They told us they would have to dig up about half of our garden, but we agreed because we wanted it sorted.”  According to Jake, the work took around four weeks to complete and most of it was completed only days before he and Chloe got married in November . Jake says that the company offered to flatten his garden to compensate for the issues that arose from the building work. But the problems didn’t stop there. Jake’s mother-in-law told the couple while on their honeymoon in Singapore that the garage had flooded once again. Jake said it was just aposone thing after anotherapos.

Jess Jackson, described as a beautul lady and a massive character, lost her two-year battle with the disease on June  leaving behind her three young children Max, seven Leo, six and Jenson, three. Her heartbroken mother Lynda Gilling has made an emotional appeal to other young women to make sure they attend their cervical screening appointments. Lynda said: My daughter knew what she wanted in le. She loved doing things with her three children outdoors, like taking them to the park. They were her world. Jess, who lived in Rumney, Cardf, first noticed typical signs of cervical cancer - which can include unusual bleeding and pelvic pain - at the age of just . After tests were carried out in hospital, it was confirmed that the disease was present. I was shocked more than anything . She was so young to have cancer. It was heartbreaking, added Lynda. Jess, fondly known to family members as aposJapos, then underwent several rounds of chemotherapy which her mum said made her sick and led to her losing her hair.  Despite making small signs of progress, in January this year the cancer was found to have spread to her stomach and lymph nodes and was deemed terminal. A GoFundMe page has now been set up by one of her close friends, Stacey-Marie Osborne, to pay for Jessapos funeral which is set to take place next month. Any money left over will be put into a bank account for her three boys, said Lynda. Friend Stacey-Marie Osborne added: Jess was a massive character and fought a very hard battle.  She was the type of friend you needed in your le to give you a straight, honest answer - and she did just that. She was very protective over her friends, but most importantly her three gorgeous boys who have now lost their mum to such a horrible disease. Jess was big, bold and beautul. The cancer never phased her and she never wanted sympathy, just love and kindness. Every year around  women are diagnosed with cervical cancer in Wales. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA boy with a rare disease that made him swell to twice his size has made an astonishing recovery thanks to pioneering treatment.Rachael Ravenhill, , who lives in Doncaster, brought her son for medical treatment in January  after noticing his face and limbs had become severely swollen.After undergoing a biopsy, -year-old Dylan was diagnosed with Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis- a rare and incurable disease that causes the bodyaposs immune system to attack the kidneys, sometimes leading to organ failure. Just  children have been treated for this condition in the UK over the last  years, figures show. Dylan also developed an aggressive Nephrotic Syndrome, which causes swelling due to fluid in the body as the kidneys leak protein, causing puffiness around the eyes, abdomen, feet and legs. Have you got a story  Email webnews@mirror Rachael and her husband Craig, , both feared that aposnormalapos childhood would be out of Dylanaposs reach as he battled the risk of a complete shutdown. Rachael said that it broke her heart when his condition caused him to swell up - almost doubling his clothes size as he struggled to walk. Dylan underwent a while range of treatments including high doses of steroids and anti-organ rejection medications to suppress his immune system but never went into remission. An organ transplant was out of the question as the disease would cause his body to reject the new kidney. But mum-of-two Rachael, who gave up her job to care for her children full time, said she did not give up hope of improving her sonaposs le. She spent many nights researching the disease online and says social media allowed her to connect with a handful of other families going through the same thing.Out of the blue, Rachael contacted Dr Joshua Zaritsky, a US specialist who treats children with transplanted kidneys, after stumbling across his medical work in the field. In an fortuitous turn of events, Zaritsky helped put her in touch with a London-based consultant Dr Ania Koziell who was pioneering a radical trial that would directly benefit her young son. Rachael said: I had emailed dozens of doctors at this point and didnapost expect a reply but she got straight back to me. I thought,I could just introduce Dylan to her then maybe she will be able to help us. In September , Dr Koziell offered to meet them at Evelina Childrenaposs Hospital in London and it was decided that Dylan would undergo special treatment, becoming only the second pre-transplant child to be given LDL apheresis which would help filter his blood.  In January , Rachael and her family travelled from Doncaster to London for the first three weeks of private treatment as Dylan had a central heamodialysis line fitted under general anesthetic. Travelling back and forth to the capital has come at great financial cost butt the results of the treatment have been astonishing as doctors reported Dylanaposs kidneys improved by % in less than a fortnight. Dylan travels down weekly to London and is hooked up to a blood filtering machine for up to  hours. However, he enjoys going to hospital and always thanks the kind nurses and other hospital staff who make him feel at home.  Although he is on a high dose of steroids, Dylan is progressing remarkably well and hopes of a full remission are on the horizon. Rachael has reserved special praise for the incredible doctors that responded to her emails when they could have ignored her, especially Dr Ania Koziell who spends an hour or so with Dylan every time he travels down to London.

Little Liam Scott, aged four, from Sevenoaks, Kent, has been undergoing gruelling treatments for a rare cancer since he was diagnosed last summer. Neuroblastoma only affects around  children in the UK every year but while Liam is approaching the end of his treatment there is a high chance it couldmeaning time is of the essence. So his parents Claire, , and Liam, , are trying to raise a whopping £, to get him on a plane to New York by September where he can receive an experimental vaccine.Incredibly Liamaposs parents have already managed to raise £, but the coronavirus pandemic has cruelly hampered their fundraising leaving them just under £, short.Mum Claire said: “We are running out of time, to have come this far is unbelievable but we just need one last push.” Neuroblastoma is a cancer which forms in certain types of nerve tissue and the vast majority of cases occur in children under five-years-old but it is known to relapse. The vaccine on offer at New Yorkaposs world leading Sloan Kettering Center is known as a bivalent vaccine which medics hope will prevent the dreaded neuroblastoma from ing.
